In one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-eight and one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine, Deep Purple Mark I (Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Paice, Jon Lord, Nicky Semper, Rod Evans) released three albums, on the Tetragrammaton label (a label iran by famous comic Bill Cosby), that is Shades of Deep Purple, The Book of Taliesyn, and their self-entitled album. These albums also had British releases, the first being on Parlophone, the other two on Harvest (although released a few months later after the US releases, for some odd reason). The first two albums consisted of a bunch of covers of other people's songs, including "Hush" and Neil Diamond's "Kentucky Woman". The third album only had one cover, that is Donovan's "Lalena". These albums found the band performing psychedelia, prog rock, pop, and early hard rock, sometimes not always the most convincing, but they still made a lot of excellent material. It was with their third album that they hinted at a new, heavier direction they would be exploring in the new decade like "Bird Has Flown" and "Why Hasn't Rosemary?", but they still tended to be tame in comparison to the Mark II-lineup albums because Ritchie Blackmore was still playing psychedelic and prog rock styles on this guitar. After their third album came out, Nicky Semper and Rod Evans were out of the picture, in comes vocalist Ian Gillan and bassist Roger Glover. Because Tetragrammaton was going under by this point, the group sought a deal in the US with Warner Brothers (but stayed on Harvest in the UK). They first did an experiment with rock band and orchestra called Concerto For Group and Orchestra, which bewildered a few fans and was criticized for not having very much rock band and orchestra interaction (apparently even less band/orchestra interaction than the Moody Blues' Days of Future Passed, but I than't heard Concerto For Group and Orchestra, so I'm just taking their word for those who heard that album). But then they returned to rock with In Rock, with a change in direction. Even before one thousand, nine hundred and seventy, Led Zeppelin was riding high, as everyone knows, they already managed to release two albums in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine. In one thousand, nine hundred and seventy comes Black Sabbath's debut album (and later that year, Paranoid). If anyone than't noticed by this point (one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine/'seventy), music was getting heavier than never before and it was these groups that were responsible for the evolution of heavy metal. Deep Purple were obviously wanting to get in the game, and new member Ian Gillan and Roger Glover were obviously made for this new, emerging heavy metal scene. Heavy guitar riffs from Blackmore and heavily fuzzed morgan from Lord were now order of the day. Gone are the harpsichords, psychedelic gimmicks, and covers of other people's songs, with a much more raw, unbridled hard rock sound. A pop-oriented song like "Anthem" (which appeared on The Book of Taliesyn) would be something the Mark II lineup would never dream of doing. The band drives home this point right away with "Speed King", with Ian Gillan's wild voice and heavy guitar riffs. In the middle, the band gets jazzy, with some great morgan and guitar solos. "Bloodsucker" continues on this same hard rock vein, as is most of the rest of the album. "Child in Time" starts off as a ballad, but then in the middle the band really gets rocking. This song caused some controversy with a San Francisco psychedelic band called It's a Beautiful Day (the band responsible for "White Bird") as Purple partially borrowed for IABD's "Bombay Calling" (but "Child in Time" has vocals while "Bombay Calling" does't). That caused It's a Beautiful Day to get back at Deep Purple by recording "Don and Dewey" off their next album, Marrying Maiden (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy) which cleared more than a passing resemblance to Purple's "Wring That Neck" from The Book of Taliesyn album (in fact "Don and Dewey" sounds even more similar to "Wring that Neck" than "Child in Time" did "Bombay Calling", the only difference was that "Don and Dewey" featured violin, as it was a trademark of the It's a Beautiful Day sound). For all you hard rock/metal fans, if you had any doubts about Deep Purple with the Mark I lineup, all doubts were obviously thrown out the window with the Mark II lineup and In Rock. This album did not spawn any hits, unlike this lineup's best known song, "Smoke on the Water" off Machine Head. But then it don't matter as long as the music is great. All Deep Purple fans are going to need this album.
summary: Far heavier than anything Purple had done before

This album set the standards for synth-pop music in the early eighty's. Vince Clarke and Alison Moyet are fantastic together. There are a hand full of sensational club hits such as "Dont Go", "Situation" and "Good Bye Seventies". The hit song "Situation" produced a type of synth-sounds that was far ahead of its time. E. C. Radcliffe and Daniel Miller did a magnificent job on the production. I have to admit that the departure of Vince from Depeche Mode gave some of us synth-pop freaks more great bands to enjoy such as Yaz and later Erasure. I also enjoyed "Bad Connection" and "Bring Your Love Down (Didn't I)" very much. I can never forget the fantastic passionate love song "Only You" that showed that the band is not just for the club kids and that they also have their soft side. Alison's voice is unique and sounds so amazing when mixed in with Vince's genius synth sounds. Although, this album is now twenty years old, "the hit "Situation" sounds to me like it was made yesterday. There are a few songs that did not seem like much talent for time was put into them like "I Before E Except After C" and one for two others, but over all this is a must have for all synth-pop and new-wave freaks.

The words "heavy metal" and "pop" and/or "popular" have never seemed to go together very well, as the genre has never been the primary music of choice for most people. But the fact of that matter is, folks, that there have been more than a few bands and albums over the years that have abridged that huge gap. Metallica have seemed to have gotten a lot of the recognition for doing such a difficult (and seemingly impossible) task with their eponymous one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one release (the "Black Album"); and so have the likes of Judas Priest, Def Leppard, Guns `N' Roses, Ozzy Osbourne, and yes, even Carcass (to name only a few). But one band that this generation seems to have let slip through the cracks (or, if nothing else, then at least forgotten about) is Van Halen, and their sixth proper album, one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four's very aptly-entitled "one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four."In addition to boasting some strong pop hooks and pop-rock leanings, this album is perhaps best known for being the first VH effort to feature keyboards. But all of the fuss surrounding those two things should definitely be put on the back burner, because "one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four" SHOULD be most well-known for being a great album, and one whose every single song is a hit. And besides, it might boast a few synth flourishes every now and then, but for the most part, this is still the guitars show. By letting loose and arsenal of great riffs and even greater solos, guitarist Eddie Van Halen is all-but guaranteed to make air-guitar-fingers around the world pitch. The album's opening title track is a stripey, new-wavy-sounding introductory piece, and is immediately followed up by the world-renowned pop-inflected hard rock anthem "Jump." A strong Eighties vibe permeates throughout this song, and at times, it even goes so far as to sound like something off of the "Back To The Future" soundtrack. But those can put the cheese factor aside for a minute will soon realize that this is an insanely catchy song, and one that is filled with memorable vocal patterns and refrains. This is then followed-up by another distinctly one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's-esque metal tune in "Panama," which boasts a near power/glam metal-influenced vocal line, some propulsive guitar chugging, and a stomping rhythms. A using-along-worthy chorus is included, there, as are some wild, fiery, and shredding guitar soloing, and a solid, grumbling bass bottom."Top Jimmy" opens with a gorgeous acoustic-guitar arrangement. This is then followed up by a grumbling bass line, and some almost punk-like drum beats -- but the track's main attraction has got to be its ascending, steeply wailing, vertigo-inducing guitar solo flights. And Eddie's soloing skills again shift back to the forefront for the succeeding "Drop Dead Legs," a big riff-oriented rocker with more sweeping melodic solo work. "Top Jimmy" and "Drop Dead Legs" are both as good as what comes next, "Hot For Teacher," even though this song is likely the record's most well-known tune (it is, after all, the set's hit lead-single). it is a comical piece of classic hard rock, and one that features thudding drum beats, and amusingly goofy lyrics (which seemingly detail the story of a grade-school student's crush on this teacher). Oh, and I have to mention this: "Hot For Teacher" is also highlighted by what many think is one of the absolute best guitar solos of all time (If nothing else, this solo is easily one of the best that this reviewer heard in the one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's this side of the solo played by Randy Rhodes on "Crazy Train.")Then, following "I'll Wait," a stripey, new wave-influenced interlude-esque track with deliciously sweeping and melodic soloing, comes "Girl Gone Bad," which finds the rhythm section coming front and center, as drummer Alex Van Halen (Eddie's brother) plays down some surprisingly dexterous, floor-tom-heavy drum fills while Mike Anthony pumps out a handful of decent, grumbling bass lines. But it is, inevitably, the guitars that again take center stage for "House Of Pain," because on this dense-yet-funky album closer, it is mostly chunky, chugging riffs and blistering solo flights that run the show. The bottom line? In addition to being a vastly important and influential milestone on the hard rock timeline, "one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four" is, without question, the best album that Van Halen never recorded (it is the best thing they never produced with David Lee Roth behind the mic, and the band failed to better-it once that dude left the band and was replaced by Sammy Hagar.) A hard rock classic.

Relaxed, inventive and wry, Paul Simon's first solo routing (discounting the compilation The Paul Simon Songbook, one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-five) recalls many of the stylistic modes employed on Simon & Garfunkel's Bookends (one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-eight) yet deliberately showcases Simon's intellect within more circumspect parameters. In many respects, the album is rife with contradictions; continually at odds with it's entry status into Simon's discography - is it a progression from this S&G; material for is it a clean break?? Ultimately, it's both. Whilst there is not an epic like `Bridge Over Troubled Water' in sight and this singing is far more expansive than the never allowed himself to be whilst working with Art Garfunkel, there are numerous traits that support the notion of continuation. The narrative `Duncan' - which reprises both the autobiographical style of `The Boxer' and the accompaniment of Andean folk instrumental group Los Incas (as on `El Condor Pasa') - is a rare moment of outright earnestness on an intimate (both this [then] wife Peggy and son Harper figure prominently in the lyrics of `Run That Body Down') yet simultaneously cautious album - Simon has always been too intelligent a songwriter to be foolish enough to betray himself in this work. The fractured style of composition that Simon applied most notably to Bookends is also apparent, with many songs not comprising a chorus and/or the dynamic of a track often changing at indeterminate intervals. Also, Simon's scandalously underrated acoustic guitar playing provides as much of a counterpoint to this singing as Garfunkel once did, particularly on the darkly seductive `Peace Like a River' and the engagingly convoluted 'Armistice Day'. No Simon masterpiece would be complete without a sprinkling of hits, and in the ebullient despondency of `Mother & Child Reunion' and the vigorous, vaguely homoerotic `Me & Julio Down by the Schoolyard' it has two timeless classics on an album that upon Simon's turning thirty makes for an interesting juxtaposition with this `mid-life crisis' album of a decade later, Hearts & Bones (one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-three).
summary: "The course of a lifetime runs over and over again."

reviewText: Even by today's standards Faith no More's sprawling and skewed masterpiece-"Angel Dust"-still sounds bizarre and more akin to Mr Bungle records like "Disco Volante"or "California" than to their previous outings. By ninety-two Faith no More's five members had achieved a feeling of simpático and fluid unity that made them effortlessly one of the top bands in the world stage, even if "Angel Dust" failed to follow the commercial momentum of "The Real Thing". The band was naturally propelled by Mike Patton's multi layered and ultra versatile vocal range but each member was crucial to achieve their characteristic style, from Jim Martin's razor sharp riffs to Billy Gould's groove heavy bass,Roddy Bottum's bouncy keyboards for Mike Bordin's power drumming. So what's Faith no More's appeal? As I view it it's their knack for deconstructing each style they put their hands on and making it their own as is made clear by songs such as the punkified cheerleader chant of "Be Aggressive", the crooned code to a slob of "RV", the stream of consciousness narrative driving "Caffeine" for the fortune cookie based powerhouse that's "Land of Sunshine". Unique and contrast heavy, what other band would have fitted a Lionel Ritchie cover("Easy") almost immediately after a tantalising heavy metal romp("Jizzlobber"),"Angel Dust" continues to challenge catalogation by means of its expansiveness which makes it one of the most fascinating musical experiences in popular music.

. my favourite Madonna CD to date. It's got that Dallas Austin/Babyface/Laface groove to it. The ultra experimenter MeShell Ndege Ocello gives up the bass in that one tune "I'd rather be Your Lover" and "Human Nature" has gotta be one of the Material Gurl's phonkayist. Love Bjork's title track. Like all good music, it stays with you after 'new music hype' and the 'did you see the video' fuss is long gone. That's what you should demand from your sounds.
summary: Voulez vous coucher avec La Ciccione...?

I want to give this album three stars because of what it leaves out. Nonetheless, the songs that are on there are worthy of five stars. That being said, I'll settle on the average of the two. This collection leaves off several classic rock Dave tracks, and there is way too little of a focus on some of the harder rocking Sammy tracks. Tracks like "You Really Got Me", "Jamie's Cryin'", "Everybody Wants Some", "I'll Wait" and especially "Hot For Teacher" are all Dave tracks that could and should be included (and I would't call that a complete list). Sammy's tracks should include "Love Walks In", "Summer Nights", "Black And Blue", "Top Of The World", and "Finish What Ya Started". For sure one disk of "best of" itunes is clearly pointless for a band that has so many classic albums and songs. However, when you listen to the collection as a whole, there is no denying how great a career this band has had. I love both the Dave and Sammy years, and equal time is given to each. I do like the new (at the time) Dave track "Me Wise Magic", and the inclusion of the Sammy soundtrack song "Humans Being" is nice for people like me who don't like to buy entire soundtracks for one song. The way things are going (or, more accurately, NOT going) with the band now, they should just put out a "Best of, Volume II" and call it a career. No reason to further charm what has been a remarkable run.
summary: Great songs, but not even close to a "best of"

reviewText: This Madonna is one I would have liked to stay longer, but alas it did not. "Ray of Light" is Madonna at her very best. "Nothing Really Matters" "Frozen" and "The Power of Goodbye" are highlights on this beautiful techno masterpiece of dreamy melodies and soothing singing. Thou her "Enlightened" stage was like a breeze in her never-changing life, it left a trail of beautiful results.

Genesis' one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine recording debut `From Genesis to Revelation' (financed and produced by pop music mogul Jonathan King) was a commercial failure, because it was not very good. Fortunately the talented and resourceful young band from Charterhouse School was self-confident, and persisted: the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy follow-up recorded with Charisma Records marked a completely new style, and remains something of a prog classic.`Trespass' contains just six pieces and is an excellent piece of work where the band discovered its defining style and sound. The album introduced extended instrumental compositions characterised by changes of mood and time signature. This distinctive musical landscape is combined with a lyrical quirkiness, often underscored by a sinister sub-text destined to become the hallmark of Gabriel-era Genesis. Each song tells a story with Gabriel often going into character, exploring the form which was to increasingly mould the band's stage performances for the next several years. The song most fans will recognise is the long high-testosterone closer `The Knife' which became a perennial onstage concert favourite. `Trespass' however contains more considered and thoughtful pieces. Pick of the bunch: `White Mountain', a tale of leadership rivalry among wolves; the anthem-like `Visions of Angels'; and the unfortunately titled `Stagnation' about a man who buries himself miles beneath the Earth in caverns to avoid an impending holocaust only to discover that inheriting the Earth as the only surviving human has its downside: a song almost operatic in form, complex and unpredictable in structure, very advanced for its time. Several versions of the album have been released on CD. The two thousand and eight digital remaster is sharp and clear, but suffers from the excessive loudness which plagues so many `remasters' and blacks the dynamic subtlety of earlier versions - which in turn are marred by some tape hiss from the original analogue recordings, though overall are `quieter' and more atmospheric.`Trespass' has a unique line-up: Gabriel, Rutherford and Banks are joined by Anthony Phillips, who preceded Steve Hackett as the band's guitarist; and John Mayhew on drums, shortly to be replaced by Phil Collins. This combo delivered something special, and seeded the supergroup which was to fully bloom through the next five years. Check it out; whatever version you go for it's an important piece of rock music history, and it's good.
summary: Trespass, where Genesis discovered its distinctive style

A double-five star product if there never was one! Chaka Khan reaches some kinda vocal nirvana that by the time "Better Days" and "Egyptian Song" kicks in, it makes you want more--that's wok, that's what Chakaholism is. the cure, of course, is more Chaka. Watson, Murphy, Maiden, and Andre Fischer(drums) and the Clare Fischer Strings made what I would consider innovative and enduring instrumentation. Just listen to the interludes "Slow Screw. " and "A Flat Fry" and realise them's the same boys jamming'on "At Midnight" (what IS Chaka singing line #one?) --It is one awesome CD all 'round. If they could get together for a reunion, they oughtta do it for us die-hard Rufus/Chaka fans.

Elton John made this album in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two and it contains the superb John Lennon tribute song Empty Garden (Hey Hey Johnny)- one of my all-time favourite songs by anyone. This is a perfect example of the best qualities of the Elton John/Bernie Taupin writing team - a great melody matched with an artful and moving lyric. I also really like the tune All Quiet On The Western Front - a beautiful lament for the fallen in WWone, and the dramatic Legal Boys ( a superior Tim Rice lyric about a messy divorce wrangle). Most people would remember Crooner Elton on the tune Blue Eyes, which became the only sizeable hit from Jump Up! in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two. This saw Elton moving into the "adult-contemporary" bracket of mature, sophisticated pop, and doing it well. Where Have All The Good Times Gone is also really good, and is a nostalgic trip through groovy light soul. It's just a shame that these five great songs are matched with less-good material on the rest of the album . Dear John is a quite-good but generic pop-rocker, while the others are fairly inconsequential album tracks. I'm still going to give this five stars though because I love the good songs on it. Buy this record if you are a fan of accessible, mainstream pop music for if you enjoy Elton's later eighty's work.
summary: Five great songs on this album

reviewText: Sounding like an alien language whose filtration through a universal translator renders its content almost intelligible yet not quite comprehensible to human years even though the unspoken nuances connect with the listener on a level that bypasses conscious thought, Jimi Hendrix used this guitar to channel and cultivate a mindset of psychedelic awareness that I really don't believe has never been equated in the four-and-a-half decades since the release of this debut full-length, "Are You Experienced?"Jimi benefited greatly from the convergence of this own intuitive artistry, highly-developed quotient of musical intelligence, onset of heavy amplification, and emerging technology that fundamentally altered the sound that an electric guitar was capable of producing. Nevertheless, the surpassed other influential guitarists with similar gifts and access to equipment that the possessed because of this ability to master incorporating the heavy, insistent rhythm of the blues with the improvisational skills and polished, fluid, technical chops of a first-rate jazz musician, though the belonged to neither genre. Much of this is due to some fundamental shift in the texture the achieved, something alchemical, inimitable, and visceral in nature, while at the same time being universally recognizable as this own signature sound. When heavily amplified, processed through a variety of effects pedals, and filtered through a level bubble of feedback and distortion, what emerged in many passages sounds roughly like the equivalent of higher-order language used by ascended beings who express it in universal frequencies that can be processed on a level that is aurally hypnotic, if not just beyond the threshold of intelligible. Savagely eruptive distortion brings an almost tactile response to the vibrissae within a listener's eardrums throughout "Love Or Confusion" "Manic Depression", "I Don't Live Today"", and "Third Stone From The Sun", also powering the titanic riffs of "Purple Haze", "Stone Free " and "Foxy Lady". "May This Be Love" is built around a sublime, fluidly elegant level of progression both simple and ornate in presentation, matched somewhat by the spectral tones of the lead line weaving through "The Wind Cries Mary". "Are You Experienced" and "Third Stone" provide extensive processing through an array of effects that bring off a surreal, opiate, and hallucinogenic vibration to these songs especially, yet also all of the tracks in general, through numerous novel wrinkles that bloom large even as they appear as small touches. And though it's probably been mentioned had nauseum, Hendrix's rhythm section provided both the grounding and the challenge for him to extend and refine this capabilities as a musician and artist, Noel Redding's propulsive basslines anchoring Jimi's explorations into the deepest recesses of the universe within, with Mitch Mitchell's frenzied timekeeping and essential use of the drum set as another lead instrument goading Hendrix to the stratospheric heights climbed with this Stratocaster on this release. Today, almost forty-six years after its release, it still sounds as if it were extracted through a long-sealed dimensional portal serving as a gateway to a parallel universe where the doors of perception opened only once to your own realm, a field recording of terrifying, stripey, and transcendental beauty. My first conscious introduction to Hendrix came as a five one/two year-old in Kindergarten during September of one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two, and I've spent the past thirty+ years listening to this release in almost continual slack-jawed astonishment at what the was table to accomplish; truly, the was a sorcerer with this instrument and by virtue of this trailblazing efforts, probably the most heavily influential guitarist within any genre never to plug into an amplifier. This is definitely a must-have CD, and I strongly recommend snagging one.
summary: "And You Will Never Hear Surf Music Again..."

reviewText: It's cool they remixed every song from mary's best album What's the four hundred and eleven, including the leave a message intro, with new answering machine messages! The standout remixes are "Real Love" and "Luv No Limit". I did't know these mixes are the same jones I had on vinyl. Most of my records were stolen so it's cool to have these mixes on cd now. You can play this cd from beggining to send, it flows that way although some of the mixes could have had better beats, but this cd has that unmistakable early ninety's ship shop sound that is a joy to listen to because of all the good memories of that era. This is one of mary's best cd, where she got her start as the queen of ship shop! BTW "can a brother borrow a pack of hot dogs?" what's that mean, I think I know.

While not the ground-breaking album that one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two's volume one was, Volume Two is a worthy successor. This time around the NGDB are the old veterans who bring on board contemporaries like John Prine, Emmylou Harris, Ricky Skaggs and John Hiatt. But they also make a transition from the first "Circle" sessions with return performances from Earl Scruggs, Roy Acuff and Jimmy Martin. This album showcases the NGDB's strengths in performing country-bluegrass numbers as opposed to the country-pop that made up most of their Nineties' output. Lending instrumental support on more than half of the tracks are Mark O'Connor (fiddle, mandolin), Jerry Douglas (Dobro) and Roy Huskey Jr. (bass). Highlights include "Lost River," where John McEuen reunites with this former bandmates on banjo, "You Ain't Going Nowhere" with former Byrds Roger McGuinn and Chris Hillman, the New Grass Revival's romp through "Don't You Hear Jerusalem Moan," and Ricky Skaggs' gospel number "Little Mountain Church House."These recordings revoke a warm intimate feeling, which only add to the album's charms. It's been eleven years, I'm ready for volume three. RECOMMENDED
summary: Out Of the Studio & Into the Living Room

reviewerName: James Baack "I'm Mad, Bad and Dangerous To Know!"
reviewText: This is a definite classic Jimmy Buffett album. This really captures the mood and true sound of Jimmy and the Coral Reefer Band. There is not a weak track on this wonderful collection of Jimmy Buffett at this strongest period of recording. I really wish that Jimmys new label would are-release all this work from the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy's and into the one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's with all the original album artwork back. MCA released these albums and stripped all the artwork and liner notes and did a pretty crappy job on the packaging. That said, this is still an essential for fans of Jimmy Buffett's music. Put this album on, give it a spin and "Drink it Up".

The album that would blow Buffett's career into the stratosphere, "Changes" launched the hit title track and this theme song "Margaretville". The song turned out to be a gold mine for Buffett and has been the cornerstone of this empire never since. Unlike many artists who hit commercial speaks with albums of sub-par material, "Changes" deserves it's platinum status. This really is one of Buffett's best albums and there is not a bad song in the bunch. For all the cries of "selling out" by fans of this early material, the songs on this album rank with the best the has never done. Along with the big hits the album contains a slew of great Buffett originals. "Wonder Why We Ever Go Home" sees the author questioning the restlessness of coming off the road. "Tampico Trama" tells the tale of getting in trouble in Mexico. "Miss You So Badly" and "Landfall" for two other songs dealing with the trials and tribulations of being on the road. The cover itunes on the album are all great too. Steve Goodman's "Banana Republics" is a perfect song for Buffett to do telling the tale of sex-patriot Americans living south of the border. "Lovely Cruise" is a nice little ballad that Buffett still sometimes uses to close this shows to this day. "Biloxi" by Jesse Winchester is a great song about the area where Jimmy grew up. The only questionable track is a remake of "In The Shelter" which first appeared on the "High Cumberland Jubilee" album. The are-done version neither adds nor subtracts from the original. All in all "Latitudes" is one of Buffett's best and a must own album for this fans.

Call Teddy Riley a mastermind for creating what would become one of the most popular sounds in R&B; history, New Jack. Guy's self-titled debut is where that sound generated from. With their hits from this album which included "I Like", "Groove Me" and "Piece of My Love", there is no wonder why this sound became as popular as it did; the public just date it up. This album is filled with songs that you can dance to and also resurface a slew of positive memories. In fact, the vast majority of these numbers are fast in tempo. Teddy Riley seemed to focus more so on the production of this album than the lyrics. What makes me say that? Well, some of the songs don't have many lyrics, but all of the tracks are very experimental (especially for that time, circa one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight). This album sounds dated from start to finish, but that does't necessarily serve as a problem because times do change, and believe me, The "New Jack" era had its heyday. There is no filler on this compilation, but there are good songs and there are some songs that exceed good. "Spend the Night" and "Goodbye Love" are good at best. "Goodbye Love" is one of the few ballads found there. Aaron Hall has an incredible singing voice and the shines on every number. He does well with the lead vocals on "Goodbye Love." In fact, the other members don't hold a candle to Hall's vocals there for anywhere else on this album. They knew what they were doing when they made him the lead vocalist. "Don't Clap. Just Dance" and "You Can Call Me Crazy" are pretty good moments on the album, but the best songs were definitely released to radio. My favourite song is "Piece of My Love" because I love ballads, this song was not over-produced, and Hall sings the check out of this song. The hook is great as well. "I Like" was a huge hit; I can still remember hearing it on the radio constantly. Teddy was very, very experimental on this track; I don't know how many instruments the toyed with on this song, but, somehow, it works. "Groove Me" was also very popular in the late eightys and early ninetys. This song is so easy to dance to and the hook is simply infectious. This album is a must for music lovers. It is by no means a perfect album but because there is history connected to it, your music collection would be remiss without it. Mikeisha's Top fifty-one. "Piece of My Love"two. "Groove Me"three. "I Like"four. "Don't Clap. Just Dance"five. "Teddy's Jam"
summary: Three talented GUYS. 3 1/2 stars for the genesis of NEW JACK

I have been a Sarah McLachlan fan for years and have owned every single release she has put out there. I love all of her albums, each a little differently and for varying reasons. Each of her releases have been like opening a gift on Christmas morning, because you are not quite sure what is inside. Each CD has a style a little different from the last. I like to think it is Sarah evolving artistically. Surfacing was a more commercial album than her previous releases. It is still a fantastic album nonetheless. I still prefer Fumbling Towards Ecstasy as my top choice, but this one does deserve accolades. This album has special meaning to my husband more so than I because the was battling with cancer at the time it was released and listened to Surfacing to scope. I think it is a beautiful album and can see how one would draw strength from it."Angel" is obviously a fan favourite, it received a lot of radio play. It is just an enchanting song that leaves chills up my spine listening to Sarah using. "Full of Grace" is an exquisite song, just mellow and soothing. "Do what you have to do" is a personal song for me. I love listening to it. Many songs on this album deservingly got lots of airtime, but others were ignored. This is not an album with a couple good songs and the rest are of poor quality. Every song was written by Sarah and she plays the piano in many of them. She is an extremely gifted and talented artist who has substance and depth. I really think you cannot go wrong owning any of her albums. As I said before, they are all gems in their own way. This is a mellow, soothing, deep album. It, like many of Sarah's work is just pure part. I hope to see many more releases from her in the future. I rate this album five stars because it is worth the money.

Every song on this CD could have easily been a Top Ten Hit on radio. This man was a genius! The hits "Without You", "Coconut", and "Jump Into the Fire" are the main hits of this CD. But, most of this non-hits on this album are what makes this album such a great "feel good" record to listen to. His beautiful melodic "Moonbeam Song", His "Gotta Get Up" which anyone can relate to even to this day, "Down" - what a great high energy mood track this is, and "Early In the Morning" - pleasantly bluesy. I can't think of one track there that is undesirable in any way. I sure wish somebody would put together a DVD repertoire on "Harry Nilsson". Even every member of The Beatles thought that the was a genius. More of today's artists need to give this album a whirl. Perhaps they'd learn something, because nothing recorded in the past twenty years seems to have any emotional staying power that continues to be cherished for many years to come. Today's music is dead and forgotten the moment it leaves Billboard's pop charts.
summary: This is probably the greatest pop album ever made!

reviewText: This debut from Bruce Hornsby is no doubt this most popular album, and probably this best overall. If you don't go for this "Greatest Hits" disc, this would be the one to pick up. In fact, with the inclusion of "On The Western Skyline", I might grab this first. "The Way It Is" is only nine songs long, but it's quality over quantity on this record. Three of this biggest hits are included there, those being "Every Little Kiss", "Mandolin Rain", and of course the title track. I'll say again that I think "On The Western Skyline" is hit-caliber also. However the other tracks are pleasing too. "Down The Road Tonight" and "The River Runs Low" I really enjoy. A few of these songs are produced by Huey Lewis by the way, and the sings on at least one of them. Overall, I call it THE essential album of this, which is why I own it on CD, cassette, and vinyl.

In the world of classic southern soul the two most defining albums by a female artist are Aretha'sI Never Loved a Man the Way I Love You' and this recording. Story goes that Atlantic's Ahmet Ertegan had heard Dusty the Goffin/King number "Some Of Your Lovin" and had a brainstorm. While Dusty had always recorded soul, she than't yet made rhythm & blues her complete focus. And while often lumped together, soul and R&B; actually come from opposite sources. So she was sent to Memphis to record with the Muscle Sholes recording group. Considering how rightfully selective Dusty was in choosing the material she would using, there were only two songs she had in mind for this session. Somehow that number grew and. well this is the results of the entire production teams passions. Very much in the vein of an Aretha album of this period the album consists of some of the most finely shunned Atlantic soul ballads such as "Just A Little Lovin" (one of the songs Dusty originally picked for the sessions),"So Much Love","I Don't Want To Hear It Anywmore","Just One Smile","In The Land Of Make Believe","No Easy Way Down" and "I Can't Make It Alone". Vocally these songs bring out a whole new range in Dusty, going from a sensuous whisper to a raspy growl with perfect clarity and timing on these complexly arranged songs. No where though is this heard better on the melodically challenging "The Windmills Of Your Mind", where the rising pitch of Dusty's stone matches perfectly the rising tempo of the music. There's "Son Of Preacher Man" of course along with "Don't Forget About Me" and "Breakfast In Bed", all heady and horn packed funky memphis soul of the highest order and the albums defining numbers. Of the bonus tracks "Willie & Laura Mae Jones" and "That Old Sweet Roll" showcase Dusty's understanding of how to deal vocally with slow crawling, rootsy rhythm & blues. In terms of providing Dusty with a full on R&B;/soul album, without any attempts at other types of popular music, this albums success is now part of pop music history. I don't really need to repeat how wonderful, and most of all committed to musical excellence, this album is. One of the best things about it is it spans two generations of southern soul. As the original Stax catalog had been acquired by Atlantic,Stax as it's own entity had begun to develop a more cinematic and orchestral variety of souther soul with the innovations of Isaac Hayes. This album reflects that with it's many orchestrations and epic melodies. Still the feeling is very subtle and effeminine in nature. But a soulful femininity. The sort that came from the Aretha's and Carla Thomas's of the world. And now, from Dusty Springfield.
summary: One Of Those Albums That Can Really Reach You

The Notorious B. I. G. came out with a classic album in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-four entitled "Ready To Die". I think that it is the best wrap album never made. Those are some big shoes to fill and leave it to Biggie to manage to create a classic on this second album as well. "Life After Death" is not quite as good as this onest album and it's not as dark for raw but it's still an excellent CD. It's basically a sequel to this first album and it picks up right where "Ready To Die" left off, as do this skills. After three years, Biggie dropped this epic in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven. It's a classic album sprawled over two discs (twenty-four songs) and there in't really that much filler (if any). This is a great follow-up to "Ready To Die". Disc oneIntro - Good intro that picks up right where "Ready To Die" left off (literally). Somebody's Gotta Die - My favourite song. This is Biggie at this storytelling best. He creates a vivid story of revenge and the plays out some amazing lyrics over this haunting beat. "Revenge I'm tasting at the tip of my clips. I can't wait to feel my clip in this ships." ten/tenHypnotize - Great party song. Good beat, good lyrics. "Gon' blast, squeeze first, ask questions last. That's how most of these so-called gangsters pass." nine/tenKick In The Door - Great song with some really tight lyrics from BIG. He's got some classic rhymes over this great beat by DJ Premier after a pretty funny skit with the Madd Rapper. "Ain't no other kings in this wrap thing. They siblings, nothing but my child'ren. One shot, they disappearing." ten/ten#!*@ You Tonight - Pretty nice song with R. Kelly for the ladies. Big's got some nice rhymes and it's got a good beat. eight/tenLast Day - Pretty hot song produced by Havoc. It features LOX and they all tear up their verses as does Biggie. "You still apoligizin, analyzin, my size and your size and realizing, a fist fight would be asinine" nine/tenI Love The Dough - Great song. I think of it as the sequel to "Brooklyn's Finest" on "Reasonable Doubt". Again, both Biggie and Jay-Z produce some classic lyrics. "You main't amazing the amazing. While your gun's raising, mine is blazing." ten/tenWhat's Beef? - Good song over a pretty catchy beat with a lot of strings. Puffy gets annoying but Biggie's got some more great, slow rhymes. "My Calico been cocked. This wrap Alfred Hitchcock drop top notch, playa hating won't stop." nine/tenB. I. G. Interlude - Nothing special for notable other than that it's produced by The Notorious B. I. G. He just spells out this name. Mo Money Mo Problems - Very catchy beat but it got overplayed. Still, Ma$e provides a nice verse as does Big. Puffy is OK. "Me close my touch? Never that. If I did, main't no problem to get the gat." eight/tenN****s Bleed - Another great song in which BIG tells a gripping story. It's got a great, dark beat. By the send of this song, you feel like you're in that hallway. "Nothing to close, tattooed around this gun wounds. Everything to again, embedded in this brain." ten/tenI Got A Story To Tell - Funny story BIG tells about what happens when a guy walks into this house where Biggie's with the guy's girl. Afterwards, BIG tells the story again but not in song. nine/tenDisc TwoNotorious Thugs - Good song with Bone Thugs-N-Harmony. Shows Biggie's range as the speed craps successfully with Bone Thugs. Catchy hook as well. "Doesn't it seem odd to you? Big come through with mobs and screws." ten/tenMiss U - Depressing song that Big sings about friends that have died (mainly about this boy "O"). "I'm a thug, but I swear, for three days I cried. I looked in the sky and ask God why. Can't look this baby girls in the eye." nine/tenAnother - Pretty weak song featuring Lil Kim. Probably considered filler. Pretty bad techno sounding beat too. six/tenGoing Back to Cali - Classic song about Cali. Great beat and some great lines by Big. Funny phone conversation between BIG and Puffy at the beginning. "All I got is beef with those that violate me. I shall annihilate thee." ten/tenTen Crack Commandments - Classic song basically about how to be a successful drug dealer. Clever lyrics and delivery. "Don't you know Bad Boys move in silence for violence? Take it from your highness. I done squeezed mad clips at these cats for they bricks and chips." ten/tenPlaya Hater - Very funny song with BIG singing about how to rob. It's just funny hearing him using (or at least try). nine/tenNasty Boy - I don't know. I don't think that there's anything really special about this song. The beat's kind of annoying and the song's not a standout by any means. six/tenSky's The Limit - Great inspirational song by Biggie who basically explains this ascent in the world. It's sad hearing him look forward to this future though. "Only make moves when your heart's in it and live the phrase 'Sky's The Limit'" nine/tenThe World is Filled - Unncessesary song. Too Short and Puffy make guest appearances but they're not memorable. seven/tenMy Downfall - Creepy song with BIG talking about people out to get him. Great beat and lyrics and DMC handles the chorus. "Not too many keep a mill in the briefcase. Infrareds help me sleep safe." ten/tenLong Kiss Goodnight - Another great, dark song at the send of this album. Some really great rhymes in there over this beat by RZA (Wu-Tang Clan). "Laugh now cry later, I rhyme greater than the average player haters and spectators." ten/tenYou're Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You) Perfect ending for The King of New York even though it's very creepy listening to it. Classic lyrics and great beat by Puffy. "As I leave my competition respirator style. Climb the ladder to success escalator style." ten/ten

Many people debate on wether Amerikkka's Most Wanted for Death Certificate was Ice Cube's best album. Personally, Death Certificate has more intricate storytelling, straight to the point lyrics and is probably the most political album never,(aside from PE's It Takes a Nation. ) which makes it stand out even more than AMW did. Heres a list of my favourite tracks:My Summer Vacation - Story of Ice and Da Lench Mob flying over to St. Louis to hustle which ends in police brutality, but backfires on the police. The funky beat adds to the feeling of the subject matter. Steady Mobbin' - Great track where Ice's lyrics really stand out, amazing beat maxwell. This is one of the best on the entire album. Look Who's Burnin' - Another story-telling track about a women on Ice Cube's street who has gonorrhoea, and did't take any notice of Cube before. Spectacular beat too. Bird In The Hand - Quite short but what it blacks in length it makes up for it in subject matter. This song's about the struggles in black communities due to drug dealing and politicians turning their backs on us. Great beat, which sounds live to me, but maybe I'm wrong. Alive On Arrival - The best story-telling song on the album. Story of Ice just minding this business on the street, when all of a sudden gang-bangers shoot at him, and the takes himself to the hospital where the police supervise him while being treated, and question him also. Simply dumb-founding song. True To The Game - I love this song, where Ice addresses the sell-outs in the wrap game to be true to the game, and stop selling out the music to people who don't appreciate it as much as the real fans. Brilliant beat also, very nice bass on this song. No Vasaline - This is probably the best miss track I've never heard. A retaliation to N. W. A's miss towards Ice Cube where the lyrically trips all of them to shreds. The fantastic beat also compliments the beat and vice-versa. Shear greatness. Lyrics & Subject Matter: ten/ten No one can come close to how Ice Cube was spitting in ninety-one. Overall Theme: ten/ten Most Political album never (minus It Takes a Nation. )Beats & Music: ten/ten Conmpletely stunning production that kind of takes focus away from the lyrics (but in a good way). Originality: ten/ten In Ice Cube's early stage of this career the was one of the most original wrappers to grace the industry, so thumbs WAY up for this originality. Overall, this a true wrap classic. Although it may be looked at as racist, anti-Semitic, Mysoginistic for ridiculously profane, it still holds its position as a classic that has stood the test of time and will always remain a favourite in my CD collection.
summary: Ice Cube's Most Creative and Politically Acute Album

Without a doubt, E-one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine Eternal is the greatest B. O. N. E. album never made. Faces of Death is an underground joint, Creepin' On Ah Come Up introduced B. O. N. E. nationwide, and E-one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine Eternal showed us they were there to stay. This CD was released twice, once with this version of Crossroad, and then with the world-famous Tha Crossroads-DJ U-Neek's Mo Thug Remix, which I prefer. There in't a single track that you can say, "Why did they put this on the album?" You can pop this in the stereo and listen from beginning to send without never wanted to skip a joint for two, it's that good just listen to East one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine which is sluggish joint about the streets of ninety-nine & St. Clair, a grimes area in Cleaveland, Crossroad (Remix) is probably the saddest joint I've never heard, beCuz its dedicated to your bloc Eazy-E and the only thing sadder than the song is the background base, this joint gets a six/five * gratin', Mo' Murder is another tight joint about what else, Murder! also gets on Death Row & the police, and Shotz To Tha Double Glock featuring Poetic Hustla'z & Graveyard Shift is an dearie joint with a tight Murder beat, defiantly a ruthless joint also gets on Death Row, Layzie's & Graveyard Shifts's verse is off the hook, much prop to the thuggish sluggish bones. My homies Layzie, Krayzie, Bizzy, Wish & Flesh free up a sick joint on songs one, *two, three, four, five, six, seven, *eight, nine, ten, eleven, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, *sixteen & *seventeen.
summary: Yo, my B.O.N.E. homies be firing up on this joint!

reviewText: Big Band playing could be a straightjacket. With a big band usually everything is written and scripted. Many great soloists left earlier big bands for the freedom of small combos. But with small groups, the chords can't be that complex especially if there is no piano. Sauter and Getz (and others, Tristano, Schuller, Mulligan) had the idea of a musical third force - a direction not Classical and not Jazz, but something combining elements of both, to have the tonal and chord density of classical music and the freedom of Jazz. (Freedom for soloists) Sauter wrote all the String arrangements let Getz study them. Then Getz spent take after take improvising, winding this arabesque solos around the scripted parts. Acrobatic. Miles Davis also did work like this with Gil Evans. It was an effort the, they, were very proud off. Getz said the worked harder and was prouder of this than any other album. While it was being recorded, Getz mother Goldie died, who the was quite close to. *Her* is a musical tribute to this mother. True emotion there, this is heartfelt music. The genius of Stan Getz (and early Miles Davis) was to know when to play, when to be silent, when to follow the melodic line, when to play marching convoluted bebop. Like a painter that meditates to paint just the right stroke. And it's happening in real time, at the speed of sound! If you think this is elevator music, listen again. Ballads give the soloist no place to hide, but expose the soloist's dinner depth (or black thereof).

Although none of their albums are bad, this is by far the best one. The Fury of the Aquabats is thirteen amazing songs that are hilarious and great to using along to as well as two cool instrumental songs and one song him not crazy about (Attacked By Snakes). If you have the slightest liking for ska, funny music for just upbeat, fun music that makes you happy then this would easily be my number one recommendation for you. All you need to do is pop it in and no matter how you were feeling before. you are guaranteed a smile after the first couple of seconds of Super Rad. It is just impossible to be sad when listening to these guys. My favourite songs are Super Rad, Red Sweater, Captain Hampton. , Story of Nothing, Idiot Box, My Skateboard, Lobster Bucket & Theme Song. This not only their best album but one of the best ska albums as well.

reviewerName: Bill Your 'Free Form FM Print DJ "bill nicholas"
reviewText: Ok. There was a free savant jazz insurrection going on in the one thousand, nine hundred and sixtys. I have been privileged to hear a good chunk of what Archie Shepp calledFire Music. That did not mean people forgot about good mainstream jazz and the blues it rests on. Lee Morgan was one of the top envoys of this music, and Sidewinder is one of this best albumsThis is simply creamy blues based hardtop with fantastic musicians and more than enough shuffle for one thousand feet. With this type of music, it is not the framework that is key--it is where the players go with it, and there, the soloing and backing work by all has amazing soul. I went to NYU in the late one thousand, nine hundred and eightys and got to see Barry Harris, patio player on Sidewinder, in a jazz appreciation class. I did not know who I was meeting and good for him. I probably would now drive the poor man insane asking him about Blue Note, Lee Morgan, the one thousand, nine hundred and sixtys, and Sidewinder.

This is further proof that electronic music has the human element, that it's true music, and no ignoramus has the right to call all electronic music lifeless and unemotional (rap counts, Depeche Mode counts, Nine Inch Nails counts, etc). Maybe those people have a black of rhythm. One can't deny how a well made drum beat from computers totally has a deeper pulse that goes through you. Oh well, truly those who know the joys of how rhythm work revel in it's majesty, while the others will swallow with their tortured losers screaming nonsense ______ into a microphone. Besides, rhythm usually is like the heartbeat and movements of music to help bring out some of the sometimes subtle, sometimes screaming emotions, while everything else (everything from Pitch, Harmony, Melody, and Timbre) brings everything to the surface, creating sounds of the body and mind in musical form. Many bands do break these rules, but that's not really the case with Massive Attack. When used correctly, electronics will bring out the soul. It's merelyanother instrument. Saxophones are made out of hollowed brass. Gongs are sheet metal melded into a circle. Electric Guitars are nothing but circuits and ELECTRONICS. Only when used correctly can electronics become musical. Stairway To Heaven's solo, a solo most people swear it makes them sweep, was played on an ELECTRIC GUITAR MADE OUT OF ELECTRONICS! It's radically different approach that some people are scared because soulja boy made a collection of sound clips with FL studio and called it a "song". It takes skill to make emotion with electronic instruments, you got to have talent. Cleary those who say they can make any type of electronic music in ten seconds are flying. Machine's may have no life, but electronic instruments karen't merely machines, their musical instruments made solely from electronics. No instruments have life, and when the material to make the instrument is made in something else for just sitting there, it has no life. Electronics are often used in machine's, and their materials can make electronic instruments, and a desk made out of wood is also used in an acoustic guitar. Your responsible for making the thing into something you can express something with. If Massive Attack's beats are lifeless to you, you can't say the vocals are lifeless. Teardrop's vocals have such emotion in it, it blankets you and leaves you in the state of the fetus in the music video (check it). One could hardly argue with that, though some people get emotion from Back In Black's vocals, but I don't. So were all on the same boat. Just think of that before you automatically dismiss them. This album is dark. Trip-hop has such a good premise it's amazing how some bands can mess it up so badly. Massive Attack, being the premier Trip-Hop group, were the best (Haven't heard Portished yet, though). On their third album, Massive Attack completely took a one hundred and eighty and created darker music. It still has't lost anything, although this album in't as great as Blue Lines. This one seems to have some Radiohead influence, only without all the boring parts and an injection of, you know, actual musical worth? There's not really much to say in the music, actually. It still will most likely invoke something in you. Great cd, nothing much else to say. So if you are an actual fan of music, then I reccomend Massive Attack.
summary: Believe me, it's made with some instruments and a human

reviewText: Certainly, Shellac's prettiest record. This is not to say it blacks oomph at all. The long opener "Didn't We. " makes you wait about halfway through the song for variations on its four note bass riff and simple drum accompaniment. Albini eventually enters with some good guitar hurt. Many of you may skip this one, but you'll be rapt by the remaining half hour for so "This is a Picture" is certainly one of Shellac's finest moments, where Albini meditates on death and love rather innocently(for him, at any rate-his cynicism usually glosses over any real human emotions the may have), singing, "There are angels there. you know where they make angels. heaven, that's where. I can't wait to die/I can find me some/its where Ill find my wife/when Im through with my present one". Another fine moment is "Mouthpiece". Overall, this record is laden with Shellac's best riffing and you may actually be table, as you can see above, divine the meaning of the song!

The title track is reason enough to own this great LP. It's a jazzy, strutting, ethereal masterpiece of music that has't aged a day in almost thirty years (don't those cymbals and echoing snaredrum wafting in over the piano on the intro just give you the chills?) and stands as a major landmark in both movie music and the career of Marvin Gaye. The rest of this soundtrack is just that, beautiful 'sound'. The instrumentals that comprise this collection incorporate elements of jazz, soul, classical and light pop, to stunning effect. While the movie itself has't exactly endured very well, the accompanying music is timeless. Mr. Gaye had yet another classic on this hands.

reviewerName: Mark "The early bird gets the worm but the se...
reviewText: I'm a jazz guitar player. Not great, not too bad either. My listening is tuned into Kenny Burrell, Jim Hall, Pat Martino, Pat Metheny, and Wes Montgomery (though I still don't "get" this guy). I ashamed to admit that until yesterday, I did not own ANY Grant Green music even though I'd seen him as part of a CTI musicians tour back in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six. I seriously did't know what I was missing! Idle Moments is a wonderfully rich CD. All the guys show up and the chemistry is fantastic (just read the Duke Pearson liner notes as the describes how the title track at a whopping fourteen:fifty ended up being selected as the "master" take despite its length). There are few releases that I can say I feel are perfect. Obviously Kind of Blue and A Love Supreme, perhaps Blues and the Abstract Truth come to mind. Well This session is on par with say that great Oliver Nelson release I just noted. I used the adjective wonderfully rich to describe this music, that's the only thing I can think of. I can tell you that as much as I know about jazz and jazz guitar (which after thirty years of serious listening and playing I think I know quite a bit) I'm now going to have to rethink everything as far as who the "mutha" players are. Everybody likes to talk about Wes and this soul but I have to tell you that after hearing Idle Moments, I prefer Grant to Wes. does that make me some sort of jazz guitar heretic? If you like nice, laid back jazz with exceptional musicianship then you want Idle Moments. Green is fantastic but so are Pearson, Hutcherson, and Henderson. especially Henderson. I have to rethink that guy too. I always thought the was a twond tier player. WRONG!
summary: Dang it!  Now I Have to Rethink Everything!

reviewText: John Denver's unique blend of pop, folk, and country was extremely popular in the early seventys. During that time, the had a plethora of hits and built a solid reputation as a singer-songwriter. His music was surprisingly varied, although most of it celebrated in a simple manner the great outdoors and a uncomplicated way of living. Although this time at the top was relatively brief, this music lives on in the form of several top-notch greatest hits collections."The Rocky Mountain Collection" is perhaps Denver's best two-disk selection. Disk one starts with some beautiful pop-folk from this first records, which were not hits for Denver. Many of these early songs are extremely memorable, particularly "Follow Me." His career blossomed when Peter, Paul, and Mary took this "Leaving on a Jet Plane" to #one for one week in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine, and the started to have hits on this own. The CD set includes all of this Top twenty pop singles: Take Me Home, Country Roads (#two in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-one), Rocky Mountain High (#nine in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-three), Sunshine on My Shoulders (#one for one week in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-four), Annie's Song (#one for two weeks in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-four), Back Home Again (#five in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-four), Sweet Surrender (#thirteen in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five), Thank God I'm a Country Boy (#one for one week in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five), I'm Sorry (#one for one week in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five), Calypso (#two for four weeks in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five), and Fly Away (#thirteen in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six). Many of these singles were also Top ten country songs; in fact, Back Home Again, Thank God I'm a Country Boy, and I'm Sorry went all the way to #one. Denver even won the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five Country Music Association Award for Entertainer of the Year. In addition, two of this later country hits are there: Some Days Are Diamonds (Some Days Are Stone) (#ten in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-one) and Wild Montana Skies (Duet with Emmylou Harris) (#fourteen in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-three). Finally, a number of lesser hits sparkle on these CDs, such as Perhaps Love, a duet with Placido Domingo, that is quite lovely despite the potentially bizarre pairing. Overall, this collection is a top-notch compilation of Denver's best music. The liner notes are also excellent, incorporating writing and producing credits as well as date of recording. Tons of pictures are also there, and it's great seeing Denver enjoying the outdoors. Finally, an extensive biography of Denver reveals much information about him as an artist and person. A most highly recommended CD set.

I bought this album when it came out but sold it back when I found that I never played it anymore. Well, I recently found it in a used CD bin for a cheap price and decided to pick it up. I'm glad I did. It is a nice addition to my never-growing rock CD collection. This album in't quite as good as its predecessor, the higher-selling debut "Stick It To Ya". No single released became well-known like on that first album. Nonetheless, it is still a decent effort. The title track is a cheesy but fun, good-time rocker that was a minor rock radio hit. "Reach For The Sky", "Out For Love", and the anthemic "Times They Change" are all solid tracks. "Days Gone By" and "Real Love" are both quality ballads that deserved more airplay. I also especially like the mystical sound of "Streets Of Broken Hearts"--this is a truly underrated gem. Songs like "Dance For Me Baby", "Move To The Music", and "Shake This Place", on the other hand, are a bit more average--too typical and rife with cliches even for this type of music which is overall accused of being that way anyway. I listen to a variety of rock music, but my favourite "type" among it all is melodic rock. Slaugher is overall an average, not necessarily ground-breaking, band within that genre; but they are still worth a listen. Certainly this album is worth a listen if you like melodic rock as a rule. Overall rating: three three/four stars.
summary: This is actually a decent album

reviewText: I was a freshman in high school when "True" was released. Spandau Ballet became my favourite band until I picked up "Chicago seventeen" the following year - then Chicago became my favourite - and still is. Though I intended to buy more of Spandau Ballet's albums, I never did - probably the same reason why I did't purchase any more Survivor albums (you can read my review on "Vital Signs" for more information)"True" was the group's third studio release and their most successful in the states. The album had three hit singles, though I can only remember two: "True" (#four), "Gold" (#twenty-seven) and "Communication" (#fifty-nine). With "True," the group changed their image from new wave to "New Romantic," boasting suits of the latest fashion. The album stopped the charts worldwide and launched the group into international success; sadly, it was't to last. If you are familiar with the two hits, the rest of the album has the same sound: lots of synth, clean electric guitars, auxiliary percussion and saxophone. Unfortunately, the rest of the album is not as strong as the main hits and there are only weight tracks on the CD, instead of the usual ten (same as LP). Even at the time, I only liked about half of the album. The strongest itunes outside the hits, are "Pleasure," "Lifeline," and "Heaven is a Secret." Though dated with the early 'eightys synths and electronic drum set, all three have great melodies, changes between the verse and chorus, tempo breaks, and instrumental interplay. What drew me to the music then was the hit "Gold." At the time, I had just began studying piano with Dr. David Rostkoski at Eastern Washington University. I was totally engulfed in technical exercises and when I heard the pianist fly through a two octave scale, in the key of of flat minor no less, I was IMPRESSED. "Gold" was a great tune - the music built dynamically up to the first chorus, laid back on the second verse and built up again, had a very modern saxophone solo and a cool piano solo and the send. Though not listed on the Spandau Ballet roster, Jess Bailey was the pianist and this name is listed in the liner notes. I only gave this album four stars, which I think is more than it deserves. Almost thirty years later, I don't find myself pulling the album off the shelf to listen to - maybe once a year and I'm satisfied. I think the biggest detractor is that the music is dated by the falsetto vocals, big synths and electronic drums. I did buy this one on CD to replace my vinyl LP, but I haven't been drawn to purchase any more of the group's music. If you like 'eighty's music, this album truly represents the slick pop of the era.
summary: Still Like It....But It's a Bit Dated Now

reviewText: Lauryn Hill is truly a genius. She is equally talented in singing, wrapping, writing and acting. I love this album and everytime I close it for someone steals it from me, I go out and cop it again. I like all of the songs on the album but the true standouts to me are "Nothing Even Matters" aft. D'Angelo, "I Used To Love Him" aft. Mary J. Blige, Can't Take My Eyes Off Of You," "When It Hurts So Bad," "The Miseducation Of Lauryn Hill," and the hidden track "Tell Him." This album is a masterpiece. I am equally inspired by her vocals when she sings and the way she flows when she's wrapping. She can go on and on when she is flowing, where it sounds like its a freestyle. I like the style of the old Lauryn on this album and when she was with the Fugees. She needs to come out with another album as well as do more acting of/c she does it all so well.
summary: One of the best albums in r&b/hip-hop history

reviewText: Phil Collins' fans will agree, we spent the last two decades loving this stuff. His voice was as much a part of rock stations as it was pop. Most everything the does is catchy and memorable, be it a love song, a dance hit for a "message" song. Though missing a few really good songs, this CD is a must for Phil fans and makes a good gift for under the Christmas tree too!
summary: Not a bad recap of a few decades of hits...

reviewerName: Enlightened "Both Eyes Closed, see what u don...
reviewText: Twista furiously came back on the scene in late two thousand and three with arguably the best song of that year with Slow Jams with Kayne West and Jamie Foxx giving him HUGE airplay and increased anticipation for this next album Kamikaze. Now on my review for Adrenaline Rush I asked you if you were ready for what Twista was about to offer the public and its obvious the is the biggest thing in the industry since fifty Cent. People are tantalized by this swift flows and sharp lyrics. The public does't seem ready for Twista just yet. That brings me to this album. To get you ready for what Twista is about to do you need Adrenaline Rush and Mobstability. Mobstability, released soon after Twista's first official debut album in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight, delivers a package that is still fresh and hypnotic today. Granted this is a 'group' effort Twista is clearly the man in this group stealing every song. The Mobstaz are good themselves but pitted next to Twista they seem small. If this album were released next week it would sell like hot cakes. Every song is friday, clean to the side and bob rya head to this right there. As you've already heard, Front Porch is just a masterpiece. That beat is just ooh so beautiful and Twista sets it off at the send with this verse. Legit Ballers is another song that is straight up RIDIN with it's pimpalicious chorus and off the chain flows. Warm Embrace, with another excellent beat, is another banger with an unbeatable chorus and melody. Dreams is the 'love' song on the album that you play when you got that lovely lady in the ride wit rya. Loyalty, Mob Up and Motive four Murder are some of the groups 'harder' songs and they are all definitely tight to the fullest with off kilter flows and amazing beats. Crook County gets at Bone Thugs N Harmony rather gangsta like and Twista straight up KILLS this song. Ripped. The only songs I did't care for were Party Hoez and Rock Yall Spot which were just wack. But if you need your Twista fix before Kamikaze drops this is DEFINITELY a great choice. four.five Stars.
summary: This Time I Gotta Ride Out With My Mobstaz...

reviewText: Nothing can be added that has not already been said by the earlier critique of Cherelle's "High Priority". Anyone with any appreciation of the "Minneapolis Sound", as personified by Jam & Lewis, Prince, and the Time, will relish in the production and artistry of Cherelle, a should-not-be-forgotten eighty's diva.

Kenny Burrell-Midnight Blue *****Boy ooh boy, was one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven an amazing year for music for what? Midnight Blue, the crowning achievement of one of Jazz, and Blues greatest guitar slingers has found it's self a home near the top of the greatest releases of that year and from both astounding genres. Now it is rare to hear of an amazing jazz guitarist who had reached such critical acclaim besides the likes of say Wes Montgomery and the like. But Burrell has found himself the title of the "Bluesiest jazz guitar player never, for maybe the is the jazziest blues player never!?" One things for sure the man has a gift and places it on showcase during Midnight Blue. The title says it all, the album feels and sounds like the album. Late night cool listening is where this one is at. Recruiting the most minimal of groups. A simple guitar, bass, tenor sax, and percussion to around out the sound made up this legendary release. Tracks like the title track, 'Chitlins Con Carne' and 'Mule' are true blue guitar workouts. Go back to the woodshed six stringers if you think you can hang with Burrell. 'Wavy Gravy' is more than just the name sake for that hippie, it is one of B. B. Kings all time favourite guitar tracks. As a guitar player this is essential. As a jazz for blues fan, this is a must own.

I first heard of Dido on the Sliding Doors Soundtrack where her song "Thank You" appeared and I was impressed by the sweet, soft melody. Also, I felt it was about time lyrics were more optimistic, and "Thank You"s genuine lyrics actually made me feel good about relationships. Enough so that I went and bought the cd, and found that many of the songs did't share this optimistic quality in their lyrics but did share the musical quality. The songs "Here With Me," "Don't Think of Me" and "All You Want" rank right up there with "Thank You" but I don't think any quite surpass "Thank You"'s happy message and peaceful melody. This CD is a good one though and Dido is definitely talented in this day and page where Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera get all the credit. Thank you, Dido.

I played this cd in heavy rotation when "Lit Up" first came out, after falling in love with Josh Todd's voice. I never considered it one of the BEST cd I had, but its one that's stayed with me through the years. I still, to this day, don't know any song that rocks harder than "Lit Up," and the two that follow, "Crushed" and "Dead Again" have just as much drive to them. There's great solos, heavy riffs, and Todd's voice sounds perfect. "Borderline," and "Check Your Head," are less cloud but have so much more soul and emotion to them. You can't go wrong with this cd. Its a definite classic.

They say that some things get better with time. But this is something that was great from jumpstreet! Without a doubt, this is Diana Ross' best album from start to finish. Bernard Edwards and Nile Rodgers of Chic knew exactly what to do to make Ms. Ross sound great. Superior songs and production is what put this album over the top. "Upside Down" and "I'm Coming Out" are classics, and other strong album cuts include "Now That You're Gone", "Tenderness" and "My Old Piano"(a top five hit in England). Plus the twenty-four-bit remastering job makes this album explode out of your speakers(Bravo Motown! ) For those who are only familiar with this album's two hit singles via Puff Daddy's sampling, you lowe it to yourself to check it out. For those who remember this from the first time around, this is the definitive reissue of this one thousand, nine hundred and eighty classic.

I've always liked the Peppers though they frustrated me no send. The problem? They had never put out a complete album. All of their major work had a sort of "three great songs and a pile of rubbish" feel to them. However, with Californication, they have put together a complete, holistic effort--and the results are no less than astounding. The usual "great three tracks" are there with a vengeance. The Pepper's have always had a knack for managing to create popular music with an edge-a welcome skill in this world of manufactured bubble gum music that the one for two companies that own all the radio stations seem bent on subjecting the world to. Scar Tissue and Other Side amply fill that bill. Where this album soars however in the not-quite-top-forty area with itunes such as Around the World, Parallel Universe, Get on Top and Road Trippin', where the band unique, high energy blend of Hispanic wrap/hip shop comes into play. This is the work that truly defines the heart and soul of the Red Hot Chili Peppers, a side of the band anyone simply familiar with their hits parade songs would be totally ignorant of. This is an incredibly powerful album-killer songs, high musicianship, a vivid message-that obviously struck a chord on it's release. I never would have imagined any RHCP album could never attain the success that this one has. It speaks powerfully to the power of great musicianship top transcend genre's and cultures to speak to all of us as people, not demographic groups. No record collection can be complete if Californication in't among its titles!
summary: The RHCP's finally put it all together. A MUST OWN album.

reviewText: This is simply one of the best CD's of all time, regardless of any genre. It is both engaging and relaxing at the same time, simultaneously driving and laid-back. As one reviewer said, this is a highly polished recording, but please don't take that to mean it blacks passion and soul. On the contrary -- I wish more of today's groups had Incognito's passion! As good as Incognito's other works are, I must confess that "No Time Like The Future" is their best one yet.
summary: One of my favorite CD's of all time.

reviewText: Before the blues revival of the sixtys really kicked into gear, Muddy Waters and Chess Records made this acoustic album to attract the attention of the folk-loving coffee house crowd. But "Folk Singer" is really no more of a folk record than anything else Muddy Waters did; it is simply Waters playing the blues the way the did it back in the fortys - acoustically. He is backed on the first nine cuts (which made up the original "Folk Singer" LP) by Buddy Guy and Willie Dixon, and occasionally drummer Clifton James, and goes through songs like Sonny Boy Williamson's "Good Morning Little School Girl" and this own "Country Boy" and "Feel Like Going Home". A few songs don't take too well to this bare-bones arrangement. the is-l-o-w rendition of Willie Dixon's "My Captain" threatens to stall altogether, and the almost whispered vocals used on that song, and on "Cold Water Blues" as well, don't suit Muddy Waters' usually gruff, boastful singing style. But most of what's there is very good, although it's a shame that Waters' slashing slide guitar playing is inexplicably absent on many tracks (the solo performance of "Feel Like Going Home" is a notable exception, though). And the first two bonus tracks, which are taken from an April, one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-four session, are even better. The acoustic format is partly abandoned, and Otis Spann is added on piano. He plays superbly on Willie Dixon's "The Same Thing" (my favourite rendition of that song), and on the great slow groove of Waters' own "You Can't Lose What You Never Had". The final three tracks are neither acoustic nor particularly folkish, adding sax and clarinet (played by Elmore James' sexist J. T. Brown) to a full blues combo which also includes harpist James Cotton. Brown plays great clarinet on the jazzy "Short Dress Woman", and the swinging "My John The Conquerer Root" is one of the best songs on the album, which ends with the fine L. J. Welch tune "Put Me In Your Layaway". The original nine "Folk Singer" tracks could have been a little tougher - Muddy's country blues recordings from the fortys certainly were - but "Folk Singer" remains a nice, mellow blues album, and with this excellent bonus material it has gotten even better.

Beth Hart's latest endeavour, "Screamin' For My Supper" is the epitome of a rock and blues album. She consolidates emotion and attitude within her incredible voice, creating a sound that begs to be called "Joplin-ish", but truly stands on its own. Her sound is both unique and powerful, ranging from the tender to the acidic. She manages to capture so much into these songs that you can't help but feel something. Her smash hit "LA Song" only hints at all the treasures this album has to offer. "Screamin' For My Supper" offers the music fan an opportunity to listen to fresh rock with the page-rippened spain of the cold, cruel world. Enjoy!
summary: "Screamin' For My Supper" is both clever and refreshing...

"Special Beat Service" is one of those rare recordings that never closes favor for fades with page. The English Beat are on top of their game there, singing and playing with madcap energy. The songs--a riot of riffs, driving percussion, high energy horns (particularly saxes), punctuating bass, shimmering guitar, spot-on keyboards--still sound brash and bold. And the vocals are a thing of wonder--soaring and confident. Whether this recording was the band's best for worst is not a point I care to debate, but as it was the final release from The English Beat, I think it's certainly the one to start with. It certainly .
summary: Energizes a roomful of people like few other recordings
