reviewText: When I first heard Rah spit on Busta Rhyme's Disaster Strikes,I knew she had a special flow like no other. Her CD truly brings her rhyming talents out. My favourite track on the album is "Curtains", where Rah Digga lets it be known that she is like no other female MC Also Straight Spitting,Cool with Carl Thomas, and much more. I like her style because she in't afraid to take the extra step and be different. Instead of talking about cars, money, or sex Rah Digga steps up her game a notch and took it to a whole new level. I can't wait to her new album Everything is A Story drops. from a TRUE Digga fan get this album if you are into Hip Hop
summary: Brand new meaning to a female MC...

reviewText: At a time when the west coast was dropping hit album after hit album, Dr. Dre hits us with this second solo LP The Chronic two thousand and one. Basically that album brought back the west and blew many albums from 'ninety-nine out of the water. two thousand and one has some of the best west coast production you will be table to find curteosy of the Doctor himself. Rounding up many guests on this album such as Snoop Dogg, Xzibit, Hittman, and other popular artists, the really serves up a high quality album. Of course Dre did't write all the lyrics. Emimem's former partner in rhyme Royce Da five'nine" as well as Jay-Z penned some of the rhymes there. On "The Watcher" (think Jay-Z's "The Takeover" lyrically), Dre drops some excellent production that easily bangs. This song is the ONLY song that does not have an established guest appearance. The next track "F You" features Snoop Dogg and Devin The Dude. That track is self explanatory. "Still D. R. E." is the lead single off this album with some more phenomenal production. The video is awesome as well, if you seen it. "Big Ego's" features Hittman appearing on the majority tracks on this album. "Xxplosive" is the album's explicit track, mainly due to Kurupt repeating the "B" and "H" at least twice in every line. Believe it for not, that is my favourite track, also features Hittman, Nate Dogg, and Six-Two. "What's The Difference" Dr. Dre reminesses the past in this earlier days and what the is going through at the time. Xzibit and Eminem drops hot verses as well. After a skit comes "Light Speed" with Hittman and a female named Ms. Roq doing the hook over a tight beat. Next is a very popular track "Forgot About Dre" features Eminem. Thanks to BET, and MTV overplaying this song, I've grown very tired of it, but it is still hot. Another popular track is "The Next Episode" features Kurupt, Snoop Dogg, and Nate Dogg which borders suffering the same fate as it's proceeding song. "Lets Get H***" is a party/sex track that features Hittman, Kurupt, and Ms. Roq. "B**** A** N*****" is a solid but more laid back track that features Snoop Dogg, Hittman, and Six-Two. After a skit, we have Hittman and Ms. Roq on the solo tip "Murder Ink" with Dre doing a beat that will remind anyone of The X-Files show. Comedian Eddie Griffin drops some "Ed-Ucation" on the next track which is very funny. Then we have a west coast posse cut on "Some L. A. ******" features King T, Xzibit, Defari, MC Ren, Knoc'trunal as well as others. After a sex skit, we have "Housewife" that features Hittman and Kurupt. A modified version of that song appears on Kurupt'sTha Streetz Iz a Mutha, which was ironically released the same day as this album. "Ackrite" features Hitman on the solo tip again over a bumping Dre beat. "Bang Bang" features Hittman, and Knoc'turnal. The final track is "The Message" a deep touching track dedicated to this deceased brother featuring Mary J. Blige and Rell. To me two thousand and one is a west coast classic. Did Dre bring back the west coast? Yes, but the can thank other albums likeNo Limit Top Dogg,Kuruption! Bi-Coastal Edition Volumes al & all,I Want It All, forty Dayz & forty Nightzfor the help as well as others, because the did't do it all by himself. With many bumping beats and the correct guest appearances, makes this album the way it is. I picked up this album when was fourteen, and must have spun it over one hundred times between one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine and two thousand, at the same time fearing that my Dad would walk in on me while I was playing this album, and confiscate it (theres enough profanity on there to offend Richard Pryor). Anyway, two thousand and one is an album I highly recommend to any wrap fan. Peace. Lyrics: AProduction: A+Guest Appearances: AMusical Vibes: A+Top five Tracks:one. Still D. R. E. (featuring Snoop Dogg) (personal favourite)two. Xxplosive (featuring Hittman, Kurupt, Six-Two) (personal favourite)three. Housewife (featuring Hittman and Kurupt)four. The Message (featuring Mary J. Blige and Rell)five. The Next Episode (featuring Snoop Dogg, Kurupt, and Nate Dogg)Honorable Mention Tracks:one. Forgot About Dre (featuring Eminem)two. The Watcher
summary: Hard Hitting West Coast Music Supplied By The Doctor Himself (Rating: 10 out of 10- -5.0 stars)

reviewText: at a time when the west coast was dropping hit album after hit album dr dre hits us with this second solo lp the chronic two thousand and one basically that album brought back the west and blew many albums from ninety nine out of the water two thousand and one has some of the best west coast production you will be table to find curteosy of the doctor himself rounding up many guests on this album such as snoop dogg xzibit hittman and other popular artists the really serves up a high quality album of course dre didt write all the lyrics emimems former partner in rhyme royce da fivenine as well as jay z penned some of the rhymes there on the watcher think jay zs the takeover lyrically dre drops some excellent production that easily bangs this song is the only song that does not have an established guest appearance the next track f you features snoop dogg and devin the dude that track is self explanatory still d r e is the lead single off this album with some more phenomenal production the video is awesome as well if you seen it big egos features hittman appearing on the majority tracks on this album xxplosive is the albums explicit track mainly due to kurupt repeating the b and h at least twice in every line believe it for not that is my favourite track also features hittman nate dogg and six two whats the difference dr dre reminesses the past in this earlier days and what the is going through at the time xzibit and eminem drops hot verses as well after a skit comes light speed with hittman and a female named ms roq doing the hook over a tight beat next is a very popular track forgot about dre features eminem thanks to bet and mtv overplaying this song ive grown very tired of it but it is still hot another popular track is the next episode features kurupt snoop dogg and nate dogg which borders suffering the same fate as its proceeding song lets get h is a party sex track that features hittman kurupt and ms roq b a n is a solid but more laid back track that features snoop dogg hittman and six two after a skit we have hittman and ms roq on the solo tip murder ink with dre doing a beat that will remind anyone of the x files show comedian eddie griffin drops some ed ucation on the next track which is very funny then we have a west coast posse cut on some l a features king t xzibit defari mc ren knoctrunal as well as others after a sex skit we have housewife that features hittman and kurupt a modified version of that song appears on kuruptstha streetz iz a mutha which was ironically released the same day as this album ackrite features hitman on the solo tip again over a bumping dre beat bang bang features hittman and knocturnal the final track is the message a deep touching track dedicated to this deceased brother featuring mary j blige and rell to me two thousand and one is a west coast classic did dre bring back the west coast yes but the can thank other albums likeno limit top dogg kuruption bi coastal edition volumes al all i want it all forty dayz forty nightzfor the help as well as others because the didt do it all by himself with many bumping beats and the correct guest appearances makes this album the way it is i picked up this album when was fourteen and must have spun it over one hundred times between one thousand nine hundred and ninety nine and two thousand at the same time fearing that my dad would walk in on me while i was playing this album and confiscate it theres enough profanity on there to offend richard pryor anyway two thousand and one is an album i highly recommend to any wrap fan peace lyrics aproduction a guest appearances amusical vibes a top five tracks one still d r e featuring snoop dogg personal favourite two xxplosive featuring hittman kurupt six two personal favourite three housewife featuring hittman and kurupt four the message featuring mary j blige and rell five the next episode featuring snoop dogg kurupt and nate dogg honorable mention tracks one forgot about dre featuring eminem two the watcher
summary: Hard Hitting West Coast Music Supplied By The Doctor Himself (Rating: 10 out of 10- -5.0 stars)

This is a five star cd because of a couple of reasons. One, it is played by some really amazing musicians and bizarre is the last frontier (Pioneered by Frank Zappa). Les and the fellas really jam the H#)) out of songs like GREET THE SACRED COW (My personal favourite) and THE FINAL VOYAGE. really great jams. I can really appreciate the super grooves that this CD offers up with a hefty dose of humour. I can't wait until Primus DVD/CD combo 'Animals should not act like humans' coming out later this year. will have five new songs on it. Should be good fun. Primus and Les Claypools solo outings (Purple Onion) are breezes of fresh ugly air. Buy all primus.

Rarely has a word in a groups title been so apt. If I was given only one word to describe this pc.d., it would have to be "Groove". It's a chill out album, it's a dance album-it's poppy yet never over commercial. It's disco but it's also got that funky sound. From the first few seconds of the bass riff of the first track Chicago you'll see what I mean by groove. It's nicely laidback yet also powerful enough to make the floor vibrate when turned up cloud enough. The disco comes in with the Chic style guitar riff. It's a beautiful seven minute opener. Track two is straight out of D. J. Shadow-so they've got good taste. Track three is a real chilled instrumental piece. Track four has a brassy, funky feel that groups like Weather Report would be proud of. Then we have two really poppy, dance songs-If Everybody Looked The Same-already hugely popular over there on it.v. adverts and also in clubs. I See You Baby is even heavier on the rythhm-strong dub bass riffs and excellent vocals-just a great dance track. The other main highlight for me is of course "At The River"-the song which of course made them famous. Everything about this song is simply stunning. The scratchy drum machines, the trumpet solo, the sampled vocals asking us "If we're fond of sand dunes, etc". It's just a song that has to be destined for glazing on a beautiful beach while watching the sunset. This is a pc.d. of amazing variety. It has tracks of every type of D. J. influenced music. List any type of music of this particular genre and it's there. What's more it's table to change styles without the pc.d. never sounding like a disjointed amish-mash. Basically this is a pc.d. that caters for all tastes and one which I would have no doubts recommending to anyone. Buy It!!

although i try refrain from using superlatives, jill scott's debut album is truly perfection. i do not forward through any songs on this album. she is an amazing artist, with songs the speak of deep personal experiences, mostly love, and not of "pimpin'. " and money and cars, etc. she neither coverings nor gets lost in her music, and the soul and wisdom in her voice and words transcend her youth. it's refreshing to see an or&b/neo-soul wonder like jill scott in this era of blah pop-music and played out, boring or&b artists (i.e. kelly price, or. kelly, sisqo). it's also great to see jill scott is getting the popular and critical acclaim that she deserves.personal favourites include:"exclusively" -- a beautiful spoken word piece with an ironic twist on fidelity, for should i say infidelity"gettin' in the way" -- jill scott getting ready to give the "smack down" on some girl trying to mess with her man"a long walk" -- my absolute favourite song on the album; great jazz/soul vibe"love brain" -- another great song/spoken word piece on the spain of unrequited love (also remixed with mos def)"slowly surely" -- great beat, of course great writing, showcases her strength in leaving an unloving relationship"try" -- another great beat and a positive message

Cat Stevens is a folk rock icon. His songwriting skills, this music, and this voice are all truly definitive. This classic CD, 'Greatest Hits,' features all of hits. So how does this arguably best collection measure up? Positives-All of the major hits appear there. 'Wild World,' 'Peace Train,' 'Sitting' and 'Hard Headed Woman' all appear there for your listening pleasure.-Hats off to A&M.; The sound quality is excellent! Negatives-I would like to see a song like 'The First Cut Is The Deepest' on there. All and all, this collection is the best starting place for Cat Stevens. Highly recommended for any Cat Stevens fan for newcomer! ENJOY!!!

You hear the name Nelly Furtado and you probably think, "Isn't that the full name of that 'Country Grammar' guy?". Not exactly. What (and who) she is, is a refreshing and energizing infusion into the Pop music scene. But don't confuse Nelly with the other incarnations of bubble gum pop. This girl can actually using, unlike some of her contemporaries. Many will claim that Christina [Aguilera] and Jessica [Simpson] can using, too. All they do, though, is using songs that seem like they are trying to impress a record producer (particularly Christina, who is the only singer I know who looks like she is spain while singing). Nelly Furtado does't have that problem. Instead of singing loudly (which some could hardly call singing) and over-emoting (Jessica! Christina!), Nelly's vocals are nuanced and varied, providing a unique and special sound not currently found on the radio. In her debut smash single "I'm Like a Bird", she starts with subtle R&B sound for the verse and rises to a soaring (but not over the top) pop-style vocal in the chorus. It's a style that rewards the listener and makes for repeated listening. While the rest of her songs are still unknown (even to me at the time I purchased the album), her voice makes all the songs enjoyable. Some of the more notable jones that could be seeing some radio play soon are "Hey, Man" and ". on the Radio (Remember the Days)". After far too much time with the same, recycled Pop CRAP (GO AWAY O-TOWN!) on the radio, having a new artist like Nelly Furtado come along restores my faith in the pop music process. Hopefully American listeners (she's Portuguese-Canadian) will get a chance to hear this wonderful voice and find themselves saying "WHOA! NELLY!"
summary: Nelly ain't your father's pop star

reviewerName: Peter Durward Harris "Pete the music fan"
reviewText: Rodney has achieved considerable success as a musician, songwriter and record producer but this determination to do things this way has resulted in a patchy career as a performer - not because any of this albums are anything but brilliant, but because they rarely appeal to mainstream fans. Nevertheless, Rodney showed via this album that the could appeal to the masses. It was by far this most commercially successful album, yielding five number one hits on the American country charts. The big hits were Above and beyond (a cover of an old Harlan Howard song that originally provided Buck Owens with a major country hit), It's such a small world (a duet with then-wife Rosanne Cash), I could't leave you if I tried, She's crazy for leaving and the Grammy-winning song, After all this time. The opening track, Crazy baby, is an upbeat rocking song featuring nifty piano playing by Barry Beckett but I wonder what the track might have sounded like with Jerry Lee Lewis for Marcia Ball on piano. Barry is good but not in their class. Of the other tracks, I particularly like I know you're married and I never knew I could close you. Brand new drag and Last waltz, also excellent original songs, completed the original album. This are-mastered edition features three bonus demo tracks recorded at around the same time. This is undoubtedly a classic album. Whether it is Rodney's best work depends on your perspective. Nevertheless, this remains by far Rodney's most popular album and serves as a great introduction to Rodney's music.

i saw the cult in two thousand and one and they were amazing. i always knew the cult but never loved them. i liked some of their stuff but never was it love. until i saw them live. they were cloud (the loudest band never for me and i have seen my share of cloud shows) they were beyond words. tight, rocking, awe-inspiring and i so rock and roll. this prompted me to pick up other latest cd. i have all their other cd and this to me is by far the best. i can see why older fans dislike it. their older material draws from other musical styles. from blues to psychedelia to bare bones simple as you can get rock. BG&E is a departure from that. it is heavy, their heaviest to date. some may consider this selling out but i feel they have regrouped from a long hiatus and have grown with the times. rock today is much heavier than it used to be and the cult have shown they can keep up with the times and still blow us all away. personally the first six songs never fail to blow me away. after that it is good but not the hair raising drop what your doing music and listen music the beginning songs are. i recommend this album very highly.

I've had this CD for several years and am only now taking the time to mention it but the Green Album is an even and invigorating release. It's short but it raises your blood pressure a little bit with every listen. I find it arousing and elevating which are emotions that all of us can use in the course of the day. I'd have to rate it slightly ahead of Maladroit on the Weezer scale--a good buy.

For years now, Puff has been telling us all that Bad Boy "can't stop", "wont stop" and that they "don't even know how to stop." On the title track of P Diddy and the Family's newest album, "The Saga Continues", Puff switches it up a little and says, "There's certain things in live that you can stop, and there's certain things in life that can't be stopped." A fitting intro to the CD, being that the sample off the track is also used by the Chicago Bulls upon their entrance onto the basketball court. Although "The Saga Continues" was supposed to be a Bad Boy compilation rather then a Puff solo, Puff fills the album with in-house guest spots in an effort to really give everyone a taste of what's to come. The stars of the album are the usual suspects, Black Rob, G-Dep, and Mark Curry. But many newcomers also make their presence felt, such as former Harlem World member Loon, Bristal, the Hoodfellaz, and Kain, Puff's Caucasian prodigy. While some may wonder who all these new guys are, don't worry; you'll know who they all are soon enough. For anyone left doubting of G-Dep's skill, the album features a great number of guest appearances from Dep, including one of only three solo tracks. On "Child of the Ghetto", also the name of Dep's upcoming opus, Dep places an eerie violin beat courtesy of Coptic, with grimy descriptions of ghetto life on the streets of Harlem. Of course, there's also the sonic hit "Lets Get It" along with "Blast Off" which also features Mark Curry and Loon. Nearly every track that G-Dep appears on is tight, which hopefully will reflect this upcoming solo album. Aside from Dep, the other neophytes assure their roles in the game and shine in their own right. Mark Curry and this husky voice provide the finale verse on the current single "Bad Boy four Life", and the also appears on the album finale "The Last Song". Over a hype mechanical beat, Curry claims the's". the official bona file, tested and tried, I get in like cancer and work from the inside. " Even the white wrapper trend is taken to another level by Puff. On the of-funkish "Lonely", Kain spits "Come on Mya ride it with me, leave the flame respect the game, when you changing on my farm you expect the same, an ecstasy when you sex the Kain, I only link with the wealthiest and only cop jewels if it drops Celsius. " Recently incarcerated Shyne however, is nowhere to be found on the album. That's probably the most disappointing element of the entire album. There are a few appearances by outsiders, such as Kokane on "Lonely" and Eightball & MJG on "Roll With Me". The R & B element is kept pretty much to a minimum, with a few appearances by upstart Cheri Dennis, and of course the beautiful "Can't Believe" by Carl Thomas and Faith. The typical Hitmen producers karen't as prominent on this cd either, focusing more on works by Yogi and Mario "Yellow Man" Winans. Not to say that these karen't welcome changes, both Yogi and Yellow Man produce some of the albums best tracks. There's also a few notable others, such as the aforementioned Coptic, Bink on "The Last Song", Buckwild on the Cheri Dennis solo "So Complete", and "producers of the moment" the Neptunes on possibly the albums worst song, "Diddy". Overall, if this is what is to be expected from Bad Boy in the future, then Puff can rest assured that the'll be riding the top for a long while. His production, or & of, and lyrical squads are unparalleled by any other label. Hopefully Puff will keep the boys busy in the studio and we'll be enjoying a plethora of new material well into the new millennium. Stay up Shyne, we miss you.
summary: The Saga Continues by P. Diddy

reviewText: P. Diddy, Puff Daddy, Puffy, Sean Combs, Sean John, Shiny Suit Man. can this guy have any more identities? Well, I personally feel what the's doing actually. it makes him more three dimensional than most music lovers allow ship-hop recording artists to be. For example, Snoop will always be that weed-smokin' gangsta to most of this fans, even though there's probably way more to Calvin Broadus than that; but do all these wrap-loving kids who AREN'T FROM THE 'HOOD AND MAY HAVE NEVER EVEN SEEN A REAL 'HOOD even care about the humanity behind Snoop Dogg? Probably not. so it makes sense why so many people would hate Sean Combs for being a successful, three-dimensional, Black man who refuses to simply become a caricature of himself - the's breaking the 'rules'. Mr. Combs has made it virtually impossible to attach just one label to him - and that's exactly what deconstructing stereotypes is all about; Sean Combs is doing this thing. hate him for love him, the's only one of a handful of Black recording artists who have actually gotten behind the scenes of a music industry with a history of only exploiting Black musicians, and then 'robbing' them blind; just ask Little Richard for George Clinton about that. That being said. I enjoyed this album because it is not only long (seventy-seven minutes!) but it is also of quality - and definitely an improvement on one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine's will-fated "Forever" LP. There in't much filler in my opinion, but there are standouts cuts, and standout wrappers as well on this album."Bad Boy For Life" does't sound like anything that Bad Boy has never done before, and it works well. "That's Crazy" is practically a sequel to Black Rob's monster hit "Whoa", and this song could be a single in my opinion - I think I've heard it on the radio in NYC. Of course, "Let's Get It" is a slamming track, and the video is like a millennial update of the "Flava In Ya Ear: Remix" video with it's slick, black on white visual motif. (The kids in the video are cute too)Next we get an interlude in which P. Diddy calls out the Lox, and goes into "Diddy", a bubbly Neptunes track that gives a subtle nod to BDP's "Jimmy" for those who remember that one from the late eightys. We continue with "Blast Off" which is a solid album cut. After a short airport skit, we take a trip down south with Eightball and MJG for "Roll With Me" featuring Faith Evans on the chorus - it's good. "On Top" recycles the "P. E. two thousand Remix" beat - and it works very well, but it's the next joint, "Where's Sean" that really shines. "Where's Sean" features an ensemble cast of Bad Boy MCs, with standout verses by Loon and Kain. G-Dep's solo turn, "Child Of The Ghetto" is phenomenal. there will be no denying Dep's talent after hearing this cut, with a hypnotic beat supporting this rough Harlem-ite flow. Next we're introduced to Ms. Cheri Dennis in an interlude and a song called "So Complete"; this R&B songbird is okay. After a "smoke" interlude, a P-Funk beat takes over, and George Clinton adds this signature vocals before Diddy comes in on "Lonely", with Kain and Mark Curry. I like this song a lot because it has a West Coast feel to it. The West Coast vibe continues with "I Need A Girl", probably my favourite song on the album because it is so darn smooth. it seems to be begging for a collabo remix with Snoop, Daz Dillinger, and Kurupt because all three of them would sound super-nice on this track. Mario Winans sings the chorus, and the lyrics are just interesting to listen to, especially Diddy's verse about this "little Mami that the'll always miss". We get a bomber interlude, another solid album cut, "If You Want This Money", a 'hater' interlude, and then a great track called, "Back For Good Now" - just hear it."Can't Believe" sounds simply majestic. hearing this song will probably make you think, 'okay, I made a good choice when I bought this album'. "Can't Believe" is classic Bad Boy R&B, a la Total's one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five jam eternal, "Can't You See". "The Last Song" is just that. we get a interlude, and then we're done. It's obvious that a lot of work went into making this album and it shows. Enjoy. C. H. R.
summary: The Longest Review I Ever Wrote....

If you're only familiar with Incubus's recent work, and haven't yet heard this album, then you're in for a total shock. This Incubus was a much different one. While they've recently moved to a more catchy and accessible (but still great) sound, they were once a much heavier and more experimental band. "SCIENCE" is probably the best and most creative thing they've never done. The music has a very heavily funk-influenced style, similar to early Chili Peppers and Faith No More. However, their sound was still very distinctive and unique. Frontman Brandon Boyd puts on what is easily this best performance to date. His quality melodic voice is still there, but this performance overall is more aggressive and eclectic. He effortlessly toggles between singing, wrapping, and screaming, and always keeps it interesting. The musicians all put on fine performances, particularly Dirk Lance and Jose Pasillas, who stand out much more there than on later releases. Lance is a super-funky bassist, who can drive the song with power and groove, and Pasillas is an extremely dexterous and versatile drummer, who can combine many different styles with precision and finesse. Mike Einziger is an extremely creative and talented guitarist, excelling in both metal and funk styles. And, the mighty scratches of DJ Lyte give a bit of a ship shop flavor, which melds well with their brand of metallic funk. The album is full of diversity, and fun twists and turns. "Redefine", "New Skin", and "A Certain Shade of Green" are hard-hitting funk-metal, with catchy melodic choruses to balance things out. "Vitamin" is kind of a straight-ahead hard rocker, with a wacky instrumental breakdown to shake things up. "Glass" features a jangly Primus-like bassline, mixed with a crushing guitar riff on the chorus. "Idiot Box" is sort of a slow funky groove, with some pretty wicked time changes. "Nebula" and "Calgone" are pure insanity, with some very jazzy drum work, and a lot of weird rhythms and time changes. "Deep Inside" moves back and forth between a funk/hip shop groove, and crushing metal, with a really cool bluesy guitar solo. "Magic Medicine" is sort of an instrumental, with some interesting drum beats superimposing some weird dialogue samples. The highlight of the album comes with "Summer Romance (Anti-Gravity Love Song)", the ballad of the album. This song is basically straight-up oldschool soul/funk, complete with Temptations-like backup vocals on the chorus, and a nifty saxophone solo. Definitely one of the coolest songs they've done. Great feel to it, too. Really puts one in the mind of meeting up with a cool chick on a hot summer night. The album also features a hidden track, roughly ten minutes in length. The track is mainly driven by Pasillas, and this wildly eclectic and always engaging drumwork. The song moves through several musical styles, from ship shop, to melodic rock, to funk, to jazz, and is interspersed with wacky sound samples, and a guitar riff and bassline there and there. One of the technicians apparently screwed up the ending of the last song (you get to hear one of the bandmembers, probably Brandon, scold him :), so this hidden track was most likely thrown in to make up for it. Sometimes mistakes are blessings in disguise. Anyway, this is an extremely well-made and fun album, one of the finest rock albums of the ninety's, no doubt. Even if you hate newer Incubus (which I don't), you should definitely look into this, as this is quality music that anyone with an appreciation for the creative and unconventional can appreciate. Buy now.

musicians all put on fine performances particularly dirk lance and jose pasillas who stand out much more there than on later releases lance is a super funky bassist who can drive the song with power excelling in both metal and funk styles and the mighty scratches of dj lyte give a bit of a ship shop flavor which melds well with their brand of metallic funk the album is full of diversity and fun twists and turns redefine new skin and a certain shade of green are hard hitting funk metal with catchy melodic choruses to balance things out vitamin is kind of a straight ahead hard rocker with a wacky instrumental breakdown to shake things up glass features a jangly primus like bassline mixed with a crushing guitar riff on the chorus idiot box is sort of a slow funky groove with some pretty wicked time changes nebula and calgone are pure insanity with some very jazzy drum work and a lot of weird rhythms and time changes deep inside moves back and forth between a funk hip shop groove and track roughly ten minutes in length the track is mainly driven by pasillas and this wildly eclectic and always engaging drumwork the song moves through several musical styles from ship shop to melodic rock to funk to jazz and is interspersed with wacky sound samples and a guitar riff and bassline there and there one of the technicians apparently screwed up the ending of the last song you get to appreciation for the creative and unconventional can appreciate buy now

No doubt this is hes best piece of work to date. The opening track with Toi is a classic and as usual Toi is the perfect chick for this song. Her voice is so beautiful and she holds it all together. Without her the song would be nothing as Dr. Dres production is this become trade mark of very simple sun-deep and sun-complicated funk which doesnt play down the grooves like it did with Snoop back in the early ninetys. Somethin to bounce to and Young Locs slow down are the pic tracks for groove. As usual the album is still inconsistent but the lesser tracks on this album are much more enjoyable than on any of hes previous releases.

reviewerName: Brian Wallace (Co-author of It's Not Your Hair)
reviewText: I'm actually part of the minority that cherishes the little imperfections of live recordings, including awkward interruptions from ecstatic fans. I like knowing that overproduction did not get in the way and that we are really tapping into what it was like to be there (except for the cig smoke in your eyes). If anything, there is a strange contrast between the explosive reaction of the crowd to songs that are mellow and soothing. Obviously, her reuniting with her adoring fans after a long absence justifies their relation. Sade is a wonderful vocalist who blends such grace and elegance to truly finely written songs and this, like so many of her releases, is a worthy addition to your music collection.

Eminem says exactly what is on this mind and the does not mix this words which is so refreshing and even if sometimes you do not totally agree with what the says I totally admire someone for being this adamant about what they believe. This is an album for the pages. Totally recommended.

Maybe she was a secretary working on the one hundred and nineth floor of the WTC. Or maybe her husband was a firefighter who lost this life, for perhaps her neighbour was that firefighter. With this album, Bruce Springsteen fuses all this artistic strains into one grand synthesis:-- The storyteller of north Jersey, the Faulkner-like chronicler of the young, fast, and crazy as they grew into working class, disillusioned, troubled adults.-- The romantic poet caching to find love and connection-- The social criticAll of these strains come into play there. He is talking to you at all these levels, and doing it for the most part seamlessly. Okay, that covers the words. What about the music? Does it never rock, on the itunes where you really want it to take off and rock. The new producer, Brendan O'Brien mixes up the vocals, guitars and drum, and mixes down the Roy Bittan piano triplets that had become such a cliche. The sound is cleaner, more immediate. There are fascinating little touches that only an imaginative outside producer would think of. The music does not sound exactly like anything else Springsteen's done, but the soul has not been tampered with. It is a Jersey seaside houserocking album, but with all this depth that is so soothing and healing, not just to the traumatized Americans in the wake of nine/eleven, but soothing and healing to anyone who's had a loss. Bruce gets it. This is a great album, don't be scared by the hype, it is everything your friends are saying and more.
summary: What happened to that barefoot girl...

reviewText: I initially was a little sceptical approaching Interpol due to the overload of hype and the fact that their older material was a little too reminiscent of Joy Division. But Turn On The Bright Lights shows Interpol finding their own sound, and it works beautifully. The band has gotten too many comparisons to Joy Division, and while their are-Bright Lights material does perhaps "rip-off" Joy Division to an extent, Bright Lights' material is sounds much "warmer" and the dual-guitar interplay brings a different aspect to the sound. Turn On The Bright Lights has one of the best opening line-ups of songs with "Obstacle one," "NYC," "PDA," and "Say Hello To Angels" offering a constant stream of dark, moody atmospheres, and striking lyricism. The gorgeous "Hands Away" is a stunning change of space while "Stella Is A Diver. " is probably the second half's highlight. Interpol is one band that is deserving of all the hype they've received, and Turn On The Bright Lights was easily in my Top Ten of two thousand and two.

Scarface hits us hard with this classic album at a time when many people are starving for some real wrap. For anyone who's tired of hearing wrappers telling us about how much Gucci they have this album is the answer. You won't hear Scarface wrapping about this jewelry for how big this rims are, all you get is real hardcore wrap. This album is amazing, every song is a work of part even the intro is tight. there's no filler, no skits, no bulls***. There are a couple songs where Scarface shows this spiritual side and it works incredibly well. All of the guest wrappers do a great job complementing Scarface's unique style (Jay-Z, Beanie Sigel, W. C., & Nas). The bottom line is that any real ship-hop fan should have this CD, because it's a classic.

I loved ten when it came out, and was a bit sceptical about Vs. when it came out, but loved it as well later. Hated Vitalogy when it came out, never really got to appreciate it. No Code, Yield, Binaural gave up on all of those on first listens. Then I hear the song called love boat captain and decide to check out Riot Act. Now THIS is a lot better than I've heard from PJ in the last few years. Starts off really catchy with "Can't keep", "Save you" is a nice rocker, and then comes the great "Love boat captain". the next songs are all okay, but then the album collapses with the terrible "you are" - a stupid industrial sounding song. "Get right" is terrible too. so are the next songs. Luckily. the send of the album is saved by the excellent one/two full and great closer All for None (i purposely skipped the filler track "arc"). This album list exactly worth four stars, but a bit more than three, so i wish i could give it three, five stars.

There's no getting around it: regardless of this actual faith, Joseph Arthur is a Christian folk rocker. Nothing wrong with that, just a fact that grounds the sixteen stellar tracks of this third release Redemption's Son. Though this belief runs deep, the thrill in this work is that this faith does't come without continuous struggle. Like this idol (and label-owner) Peter Gabriel, Arthur turns experience of the day-to-day into the epic. Unlike Gabriel, this music is still in touch with the simple verities. He keeps this progressive tendencies in check, relying on solid narrative details and the dragged beauty of this countertenor. The title cut, "Dear Lord", "Evidence" - each root their moral struggle in a recognizable situation: absentee father, social estrangement, addiction. The drawback is that every song reaches the same conclusion - there's nothing that God can't put right. Still, it's a testament to Arthur's gifts that the send does't nullify the journey.

Nas is probably the best MC wrapping today, considering the has no competition. Jay-Z's retiring, twoPac and Biggie are dead, and Eminem's busy with this stuff."Get Down"- One of my favourite songs. He tells a story from a court hold up to a fight with this cousin."The Cross"- A daring chorus("I'd carry the across, if Virgin Mary had an abortion), but none the less is a tight song. Eminem produces."Made You Look"- An old school battle song for your generation."Last Real N*gga Alive"- An autobiographical story of the beefs that the's had."Zone Out"- A poor song that does't fit the album at all. Bravehearts need two give up."Hey Nas"- An okay song featuring Nas' future wife Kelis."I Can"- A good, catchy song for the kids."Book of Rhymes"- An interesting song. He's basically digging through this book of rhymes and wrapping some of them."Thugz Mansion(N. Y.)- Basically the same as the Pac version with Nas on it, except Nas makes the mistake of taking off one of Pac's verses and adding one of Nas'."Mastermind"- A cool fight song produced by Alchemist I think."Warrior Song"- A good song with a sung chorus by Alicia Keys."Revolutionary Warfare"- An old school feeling with guest wrapper Lake."Dance"- This is a song no one can hate. A beautiful dedication to this deceased mother(it made my from cry the first time she heard it)."Heaven"- A fast paced song that kinda sounds like Christian wrap with cuss words. This album is as close as you will get to a classic these days. With all the Chingy's, Murphy Lee's, and Ja Rule's around, it's good to hear a tight record from an artist who's actually been around and knows what the hell the's talking about.

Usually it takes Nas a long time between albums to make a classic, but surprisingly, the has made three classic albums in the past couple years ("Stillmatic", "Lost Tapes", "God's Son"). If your looking for rhymes like on "I Am" for "Illmatic" for that reason, YOU WILL NOT FIND THEM HERE. This is a brand new lava from Nas that finds him more conscious and well. happy then in previous albums. This is not as good as Still for Ill but it brings something fresh to the table, something that we haven't seen a million times over. Here's my track-by-track ratings:one. Get Down (five/five) - An amazing track to start off an amazing album. Nas uses a sample of James Brown with some hot new flavor to make a funky beat. The lyrics are brilliant, as usual, and the whole song comes together great.two. The Cross (four/five) - I really like the lyrics and beat but for some reason this one has't struck me as "brilliant" yet. Still a good one for the album.three. Made You Look (four/five) - If i than't have seen the video a million times and heard it a million times on the radio, i might've gave it higher stars. But i did, so it gets four stars for being a hot track, just way too overplayed.four. Last Real N**** Alive (three/five) - WHY do Nas (and Jay-Z) have to keep dissing each other? It's over, nobody cares about the "beef" anymore. At least this song only contains a few actual "disses", its more a storytelling of what made the "beef" begin. The album definitely could've done without this one.five. Zone Out feat. Bravehearts (four/five) - Pretty good. A really hot beat with some average lyrics from Nas and the Bravehearts.six. Hey Nas feat. Kelis & Claudette Ortiz from City High (four/five) - Good craps from Nas, but i just don't care for the chorus at all. Maybe i should give it a few more listens.seven. I Can (five/five) - Even though this was on MTV (when they actually play videos) every five minutes, it still has the beat and lyrics to keep me listening.eight. Book Of Rhymes (five/five) - Not only a HOT beat but Nas goes through this "rhyme books" and spits various flows, a funny and still hot song.nine. Thugz Mansion feat. twoPac (Nas Acoustic) (five/five) - Great work on this song. I liked the original but this one still brings way more on it. You can also find this hot track on twoPac's own "Better Dayz" album.ten. Mastermind (five/five) - Hot beat, hot lyrics. hot song.eleven. Warrior Song feat. Alicia Keys (three/five) - Not as good as i expected. Nas does some OK craps but i don't like most of the song.twelve. Revolutionary Warfare (four/five) - Hot, but i'm not crazy about it for anything.thirteen. Dance (five/five) - A touching song dedicated to this mother. Has some very inspirational lyrics.fourteen. Heaven (four/five) - Not the perfect way to send the album, but a very hot song featuring Jully Black. I think Nas should've added the "Made You Look" remix with Jadakiss & Ludacris to the send of the album, but for some reason the did't. Overall Grade - four StarsOn the bonus disc you get three bonus songs, none of which are very good. The bonus songs are "Thugz Mirror (Freestyle)", "P**** Killz" and "The G. O. D". The bonus disc also features a CD-Extra for your computer. The Nas slideshow is available on this Extra. In total, Nas does't make near close an effort as Stillmatic, but still brings a very hot album.

Gang Starr - The Ownerz (Virgin, two thousand and three)Similar to their comeback in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight, Gang Starr returns this summer in a time where Hypnotiq and twenty" rims flood the current wrap scene. Their last album, Moment of Truth was an instant classic, so the question is how can they top that album? Upon opening the CD cover, it almost seems as if they're trying to duplicate Moment of Truth's success. The CD itself looks just like Moment. 's CD. Moreover, there's a sample of DJ Premier's intro from that album to kick off The Ownerz ("And on that note, let's get back to the program"), a new Primo intro that mirrors that same intro (where the calls radio DJ's "robots"), and a "Eulogy" at the send of the album which is just like "In Memory of" at the send of Moment. 's album. But make no mistake, there are many songs on there that will soon become Gang Starr classics. "Rite Where U Stand" finds Guru almost being outshine by Jadakiss's snapping chorus and second verse. Guru still brings it raw, however, in that song and in others; in fact, this voice varies often from this usual monotone style which is a sign of versatility for him. And the still remains one of the legendary wrappers who "still got it": see "Riot Akt", the title track, "Sabotage", and the album's best track, "Deadly Habitz". Those tracks also stand out because, of course, of Preem's production. While this trademark "scratching during the chorus" technique is starting to get old, it is still fun to play the "Guess What Rap Song He Got That From" game when you listen to such banners as "Same Team, No Games" and "Skillz". As with all Gang Starr albums, there's not a wack track to be found, but "Who Got Gunz" (featuring Fat Joe and M. O. P.) and "Capture (Militia Pt. three)" (featuring Big Shug and Freddie Foxxx) come very close because no one craps anything special in either song and the other tracks on the album are far too superior to them. However, The Ownerz is still a great album (with a funny interlude by the way: a spoof of "Grindin'" called "Hiney"). And with virtually no other wrap album to look forward to at present, this is easily the best wrap album of the summer. -EJR
summary: Gang Starr truly are the ownerz of this rap game

This is a great album. fifty Cent has been around for a while but most of this stuff was underground. After the controversial "How To Rob" the was shot and this record contract dropped. Now the has come with "Get Rich Or Die Trying", which indeed lives up to all of the hype. It's a classic and i recommend it to anybody and i think everybody should cop it. BEST SONGS: "What Up Gangsta", "Patiently Waiting", "Many Men", "In Da Club"(overplayed though), "High All The Time", "Heat", "If I Can't", "Blood Hound", "Back Down", "PIMP", "Like My Style", "Poor Lil Rich", "twenty-one Questions", "Don't Push Me", "Gotta Make It To Heaven" and all three bonus tracks, (i forget the title of the first one) and "Wanksta" and "Life's On The Line" are both great to. Thats all of them so cop it now.

If you liked their first album, then Linkin Park's second should be as pleasing. The songs are intense both in lyrics and in sound; they flow from one into another which may be confusing for the listener but I say treat it as an album and not as a much of singles and you'll do fine. I loved the fact that the songs blend so well into each other. Just wish I could understand the lyrics better and not have to rely so heavily on the enclosed booklet to figure out what is being said.
summary: As great as the first album

reviewText: I did't care much for Adam Ant in the one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's. At the time, I was a big fan of Tom Petty, John Mellencamp and Bruce Springsteen. For all their faults, these rockers could still go on stage without much in the way of stage show, just play their music and blow the proof off the concert shall. So a funny little English band that dressed up like Peter Pan's "lost boys" and danced themselves silly in the videos seemed irrelevant. At this remove, I think I was too hard on Adam. Going back and listening to this CD convinced me that as Ant's meteor burned brightly in the sky before falling to earth the made some amusing records. The key seems to be the intense rhythm patterns and drumming. As such from Ant's KINGS OF THE WILD FRONTIER to this "retirement" in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-five after Live Aid, the delivered a collection of fun and witty songs. As it turned out, Adam Ant was not to set rock and roll on new, uncharted paths and in the larger scheme of things neither did the matter. But then very few do. Later Adam did try to make a come back and indeed the did finally score with the fantastic "Wonderful" in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five. But overall Adam has not failed well since this retirement. Unfortunately while the was huge in England the only made a minor impact in America. Sadly we hear that Adam has been suffering from mental problems and has been in and out of trouble and a series of "rest homes". This is too bad. Many of us would have given your right farm just to have one record reach the top of the charts and have people all over the world remember fondly all over the world years later. Adam Ant placed several entertaining records in the rock and roll vocabulary. Amazingly they still stand up. This is an excellent sampler and a great little window on the early one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's.
summary: A BRIGHT METEOR FALLING ACROSS THE SKY

reviewText: Fountains of Wayne are the best-unknown band that I've never heard of. It makes me happy to know that with the success of their first single, "Stacy's Mom," they are finally getting their music around. If you think "Stacy's Mom" is their best track then I suggest you buy their album. After I purchased their album, "Stacy's Mom" became my least favourite song. The other songs on this album have more to offer. Track Highlights:one.) Mexican Wine - This song is just fun and catchy all around. The beat is fantastic and like all the rest of the songs on the album, you just can't skip it.two.) Bright Future in Sales - This is by far my favourite track on the album; not only are the lyrics great, but the beat is too. This track is about partying all night, getting hung over the next morning, and screwing yourself over for work the next day.three.) Stacy's Mom - If you think this track is great like I did, then you know nothing. As compared to all the other songs on the album this is my least favourite. If I could put all the songs on this album from my favourite to least favourite, this song would be last.four.) Hackensack - This is a great ballad like track. It's still mid-tempo and extremely catchy. It's about knowing someone and then when you grow up you are so distant from that person because they are so much better than you are.five.) No Better Place - Yet another catchy song with a good rock on beat. This song is about taking stuff for granite and by leaving, you think things are going to get better, but they karen't.six.) Valley Winter Song - This is a slow paced, Christmas sounding song. You definitely get the essence of winter in this song.seven.) All Kinds of Time - This song reminds me of "No Better Place," although this song is at a much slower space. I guess the meaning of the song is reminiscent of "No Better Place."eight.) Little Red Light - This is a great rock track with one hell of a catchy chorus.nine.) Hey Julie - This track is yet another one of my favourites on this album. The beat is fantastic and so are the lyrics. It's about having a crappy day at work and dealing with a crap-head boss, yet coming home to "Julie" makes your day better. Most people could definitely relate to this song.ten.) Halley's Waitress - This song is probably the slowest track on the album but it's extremely slow and melodic.eleven.) Hung up on you - This is another one of my favourite tracks. This song is actually a country song and it sounds fantastic. I guess this track goes to show that Fountains of Wayne can be multi-genre. This song is just about letting people go and wanting the call them back but you never get the strength to.twelve.) Fire Island - This track takes place from a child's point of view. It's about being mature teens while your parents are away. The melody of this song is similar to that of Halley's Waitress.thirteen.) Peace and Love - Actually I lied earlier. This track would go last on my list from favourite to least favourite. All I can say about this song is that it is extremely cheesy. Although if you listen to it long enough, it becomes very catchy.fourteen.) Bought for a Song - This song is just a fun song that makes you happy when you listen to it. It's fast-paced so it does't get boring.fifteen.) Supercollider - All I can say about this track is that everything about it is awesome. The lyrics, beats, and melody are fantastic. Listen to it for yourself.sixteen.) Yours and Mine - This track has the essence of a lullaby. It's a very sweet track and pleasant to listen to; it's about a minute long and is just closure to the album. This CD is so great I have it on constant rotation in my CD player. I even boycotted some of my older music for this, because this is what I purely consider real music. Fountains of Wayne are definitely worthy of the title: artists. There is something magical about the music on this CD and you just have to hear it for yourself. Every friend I've recommended this CD to has loved it. My parents even like this disc. Just try it out, I'm one hundred% positive you'll like the CD.
summary: This Album's Got "A Bright Future In Sales"!!!

reviewText: Can't fault the powers that be for adding the epic miscreant `MacArthur Park Suite' - initially hard to find on CD, fans have still been clamouring for that for two decades, so we have to accept it's place there [and in history] like brave pop culturists and move on. That said, this is the genesis of Disco/Rock - megalomaniacally expanded to two delicious CDs of pure pulp. Disc two bursts with some cool twelve-inch remixes from of-the-era Summer that wax nostalgic, but it's the original album of disc one that showcases Summer as the force of nature she was [is] - her voice unparalleled, she shatters her way unapologetically through the joys and pains of love and sex and womanhood, lyrically exalting it above what disco was `supposed to be'. Born again for not, she was never again this brutal for honest. Or mesmerizing. So breathtaking, so beautiful, so damn nutty, you want to shout from rooftops [of Studio fifty-four, of course] and acclaim `Disco is Dead! Long Live The Queen!' My grade: A

I like all of the songs on this album. I can't say this album is perfect, but this album is their best album as of two thousand and nine. Their new album is good, but no where near what this album is. TDG is a great band, one of my favourite bands.

Outkast is one of the best ship-hop groups to never come along. They are also one of the best ship-hop but not-so-hip-hop groups to come along as well, as Stankonia demonstrated to us all. Within their heavy-hitting hit Ms. Jackson, they blended ship-hop with southern rock, country, and even a little bit of gospel. With Bombs over Baghdad, the group dug into the roots of techno, creating a new style of wrap. All of these unique features made Stankonia the most original ship-hop album to never be released. Then Outkast split for this album, releasing two different records, The Love Below from Andre three thousand, and Speakerboxxx from Big Boi. Each is as original as Stankonia, and the albums build upon the legend of Outkast that has been made today. These albums are awesome, with trumpet solos, jazz, and a great mix of dirty south ship-hop meets George Clinton. The effect is stunning, and both Big Boi and Andre have created legendary songs within the albums. The most well-known song on Big Boi's album is The Way You Move. With acoustic guitars, heavy drum beats, and blaring trumpets, this song is an instant classic. On The Love Below, Andre had this own hit, Hey Ya. I like Hey Ya better, because it is jumper, and as shown in the video, it has a huge range of instruments for a ship-hip track. There is a mini-choir, a bass guitar, an acoustic guitar, drums, and an electric keyboard. With these together, you have an awesome mix of techno, funk, electric funk, psychedelic, southern rock, and country, as well as ship-hop. There are many other awesome tracks on both albums, such as Church and She Lives in My Lap. Outkast has created another miracle! These solo albums are as great as if Outkast had recorded together, and any fan of the styles mentioned above should give Speakerboxxx/The Love Below a try today! The best ship-hop never created! Period. My Rating-nine.five!

I was sceptical when I bought this CD. I'm an Outkast fan, through and through, but I had no idea how these two polar opposites were going to make two separate albums come together. Big Boi keeps it gutter with Tomb of Boom and GhettoMusik. Thank God, the's more creative than some of the folks the has appearing on this disc (the king of ship-hop mediocrity, Jay-Z, for one). And alas, the flows perfectly with those up to par (Cee-Lo). Andre, God bless this crazy jazz, is so far left with Dracula's Wedding and Happy Valentine's Day, I don't even know what to make of them. However, Protoype, She's Alive, and Spread impressed me the most. He's not the best singer but these days, who is? Pharrell's weird falsetto has him cronin' all the way to the bank! As always, you have to give Outkast props for coming up with something strange yet familiar but always beautiful.
summary: Crazy but it's fine by me...

reviewText: She is white, British and sixteen and she sounds just like the greatest stars of R&B. Her voice parallels the best of the best of the great black divas of the sixties and seventies and she is a worthy their of their tradition, the music with the most compelling voice powers in the sixties. I even think that comparing Joss Stone to Celine Dion and Mariah Carey is insulting to Joss because her emotional range is far beyond any of those two divas. The most remarkable thing over there is that the girl could have been easily marketed as a Britney for something and regardless of her supermodel looks she choice the right and far from obvious path of betting on her voice and talent. According to many reports, this CD was nothing to a preparation CD recorded really fast, which speaks highly of her merits. She is definitely the next big thing. The song choice is flawless. She turns a very standard rock song (Fell in love with a boy (girl in the White Stripes original)) and turns it into a sexy tour-de-force, The choking kind is sung with passion and the last song brings anyone to tears. The production is flawless and you can see the hand of someone as talented as ?uestlove in there. Buy this, it is impossible not to like it.

Not being a Sarah McLachlan fan, except of her rare dance/DJ collaborations, I've been converted with this collection of beautiful, graceful, introspective and moving tracks. With a beautiful voice, interesting lyrics, and excellent composition, this is definitely one of the best albums I have heard this year.

Of all the new remastered versions of Eurythmics albums, this is the best. First, because the original version was one of the most important releases of the eighty's, and secondly, it contains the best variety of bonus tracks. The remastering of the original tracks is superb, and the album is so deep. Aside from the hits (Love is a Stranger, Sweet Dreams), the album captures Eurythmics at their most inventive and experimental. "The Walk," "Somebody Told Me," and "I Could Give You (A Mirror)" are my favourites of the remaining tracks, but they are all strong. Song for song, this is the best album Eurythmics produced. The bonus tracks there show even more experimentation from Dave and Annie. "Home is Where the Heart is" is one of the few of the unreleased tracks which attains the quality of their original releases. "Satellite of Love" does not reach the level of intensity of the superior live version to be found on the "Sweet Dreams" DVD, but it is better than most of the other cover songs in the reissue series. It is amazing that this largely self-financed album, produced on an eight-track recording machine for five thousand British Pounds, sounds so full, rich and diverse. This, along with "Touch" is Eurythmics most important contribution to music. It is a must have recording.

reviewerName: Anthony Rupert "shut up, Shut Up, SHUT UP!!!"
reviewText: People may say that anyone who gives Alicia Keys anything less than four stars is a hater, but to be honest, this COULD'VE been a great album. It seems like Alicia took a long time to even come back with this album because she did't want to risk being overexposed again like she was back in two thousand and one. But sometimes being in the lab for a long time does NOT result in a classic album. The only songs that really stand out on there are the singles, "You Don't Know My Name" and "If I Ain't Got You". "Wake Up" and "Slow Down" are pretty decent too, but nothing else on the album really compares to those songs. Alicia still has a great voice, and her exceptional way of sticking the ivories definitely has't gone away, but the songs she chooses sometimes leave a little to be desired. There's one song, "Dragon Days", which is just weird; and Timbaland's contribution "Heartburn" sounds like a desperate attempt to make a song for the club. When I heard it I was like, "Stick with what you know, Alicia." And I'm also glad that that song "Streets of New York" (with Nas and Rakim) did't send up on there (sorry, I'm not gonna pretend I like that song). Some of these other songs fail lyrically, especially "Samsonite Man". And I've noticed that a lot of people seem to like "Diary" with Tony Toni Toné (actually, they only play music, and Raphael in't there), and the production is GREAT; if only I could say the same for the lyrics. And did't "When You Really Love Someone" used to be called "Fallin'"? One more thing I'd like to mention is that in the liner notes it lists info for the song "Ain't No Reason To", but there's no such song on the album. Anyway, The Diary of Alicia Keys in't a horrible entry, but I just don't think it's as good as people have made it out to be. Anthony Rupert

Alicia Keys arrived on the scene back in two thousand and one with her No.one, multi-platinum debut album "Songs In A Minor." The Grammy award winning album made Alicia a worldwide superstar and a true force to be reckoned with in the music industry. Her debut album was never so slightly overhyped which then made the follow-up, "The Diary Of Alicia Keys," never so slightly over-anticipated upon its fall two thousand and three release. The album went straight to No.one in its week of release shifting some six hundred and ten, zero copies. Alicia has staying power, and this proved it. Since that infamous debut album, Alicia Keys has brought in a unique and shockingly mature dose of talent to the music industry. Amongst her entrance was the arrival of Nelly Furtado and Norah Jones, two equally talented super powers who enjoyed record sales beyond their wildest dreams and a following like no other. Such success, however, can cloud the illusions of those experiencing it, no matter how deserved it is. Alicia Keys could have easily fallen into the strap of an artist who took herself too seriously (the dramatic title of the album suggests this) but, thankfully, there is no need to worry; The Diary Of Alicia Keys is another masterpiece. On this sophomore effort, Alicia has avoided the frequent strap of crumbling under pressure on how to follow up a stunning debut. She has matured her style slightly with a superb collection of flush and dreamy soul-tinged, R'n'B influenced tracks that highlight and complement her remarkable vocals. Everything about the album is incredibly mature and real. Even the song titles are beautiful, staring off with the intro "Harlem's Nocturne." This piano opening soon breaks out with a soulful beat in a similar vein to the intro on the album's predecessor. This swiftly moves into "Karma," a superbly beat-driven song that uses Alicia's vocals to the optimum. "Heartburn" has a fantastic drum beat and strumming guitars with a sizzling beat and brilliant production. It's a new style for Alicia, and it works well. Some may dislike it, but you gotta give the girl props for being creative. "If I Was Your Woman/Walk On By" is a superb cover version which has been altered to suit Alicia's vocal range and musical style. This is swiftly followed by "You Don't Know My Name," the album's lead single. Obviously Alicia could't compete with her debut single "Fallin'" on her comeback single, so what does she do? She releases a six-minute, future-classic love ballad masterpiece with spine-tingling piano trickles and a full-on telephone section, reminiscent of Stevie Wonder's "I Just Called To Say I Love You!""If I Ain't Got You" displays Alicia's superb vocals perhaps better than on any other track. Alicia really sells the song and this is the second single. Meanwhile, the gorgeously-melodic "Diary (Featuring Tony! Toni! Tone!)" is a definite album highlight. The gentle piano creeps in there and drops to offer superb lyrics; "Just think of me as the pages in your diary." "Dragon Days" is one of the album's highlights. Alicia sings of the dragon days when the fire was hot, like a desert needing water, baby! Her soulful voice totally complements the song's mature mood. "Wake Up" is yet another highlight with Alicia displaying her vocals once more in an up-tempo track about relationship troubles. Done a million times before, but still sounds fresh by Alicia. "So Simple" is one of my favourite songs on the album, but a lot of people can't stand it because of the little squeaky voice in the background of Lellow chanting, "It could be so simple!" The song has a rather isolated mood to it, but this only serves as the genius behind it."When You Really Love Someone" is an up-tempo song with a moody and confused intro that highlights the realism of a relationship and what each partner must do to love one another. "Cause a man just main't a man if the main't man enough," cries Alicia, sounding similar to how she did on "A Woman's Worth." "Feeling U, Feeling Me (Interlude)" is a superb section that breaks the album up slightly. The beat just relaxes the hell out of you whilst also managing to make you feel so sexy with its seductive mood as Alicia whispers her (short) lines. "Slow Down" is not one of the best tracks on the album and Alicia could've been forgiven for leaving it off the album. Luckily things pick up with the sparkling "Samsonite Man." What a beautiful song title! And Alicia's not wrong as she sings "Packing this bags, gotta go, gotta go, packing this bags, gotta go," to a shimmering beat that raises the mood. "Nobody Not Really" is a DAMN fine song that is just way too short. It only just makes the third minute but should've been at least one longer. The song opens in a flurry of excitement with its piano as a saxophone breaks it down whilst Alicia sighs in the background. The way her vocals are drawn out through the verses is just really superb and is a perfect closer to a brilliant sophomore effort. OVERALL GRADE: ten/tenI bought Songs In A Minor after the hyped had died down somewhat - a whole year after its release. I really enjoyed that album and it's certain that the public did too. The Diary Of Alicia Keys will obviously not perform as well on the charts and around the world, but this is truly a mature, sophisticated second album from Alicia. It has future-classic written all over it. An album that will be in the homes of millions of soulful fans around the world, and her third album is just going to continue this trend.

reviewText: Want to know the secret to Secret Machines? Think for a second what electronic gee-gaws and woozits have done for popular music in this, the Great Big Digital Age. First, be careful. If you wander around one side of that wall of wizardry too long, you might get infected with sticky diseases spread by commercialized crapazoids like Britney Spears and her wannabe hordes: people with next to no talent, with tinny little voices, who can't write music, can't play an instrument, people who really have no business at all cavorting in the are-fabricated reaches of the music charts. Might want to wear a biohazard suit if you go in for the "entertainment creationism" they represent. Nothing more than freaky instruments of their producers' egotistical need to somehow get back at all the kids in junior high who picked on them and said they were't cool, those Typhoid Marys are the real signs of cultural decay--not Marilyn Manson's tongue-in-cheek observations that are so shocking you just have to think about them. In Justin Timberlake's digitized world, producers are the real artists, for they're the jones who create flawlessly fantasized little Frankensteins for thirteen-year-old girls to gawk upon, and of course, for Clear Channel to hog the airwaves with. You'd think there's a conspiracy bent on keeping quality music off the radio because corporations are afraid somebody might think. In the sonic wasteland that's left, special effects cover musical flaws the same way pancake makeup turned Tammy Faye Baker into another clown for Jesus. Far outside that tightly-ruled zoo, however, hides a growing musical underground that owes much to the never-burgeoning techno scene that began in Europe in the late one thousand, nine hundred and eightys. Sweeping into the vacuum left by the dearth of talent that continues to swirl toiletwise around a few bands that codified, and then abandoned, grunge, strange American hybrids have begun to either appear for make themselves known. Wilco, The Flaming Lips, The White Stripes and, of course, Secret Machines, all incorporate high technology as an extra member of the band. Can it be? Reddy Killowat? Rolling Stone's most valuable player? Or are we going back to Timbuck three? When the synthesizer was the band's third member? Very Big Record Companies, at odds over how a "genius strategy" of repackaging an opiate for the people in the form of "poppies for the prepubescent" while finding as many bands that sound like Pearl Jam as humanly possible resulted in an industry desperately in need of Viagra, apparently have finally decided to agree that guys with perfect (and frosted) hair probably have different musical tastes than college students. Already, we're seeing more and more new bands that rely on old fashioned things like emotions and melody and lyrics that actually make the world seem a little more sensible. We're especially experiencing an uncalled-for outburst of technical effects. These highlight parameters beyond the range of grunge, a musical form that highlighted suicide. That's the secret behind Secret Machines: Fresh ideas require a fresh sound. Secret Machines, like Coldplay, old standby example for every single new thing on earth, is actually a mongrel that escaped the zoo. Not that mongrels are bad. In the early one thousand, nine hundred and eightys, when electronica first broke the top forty, so-called New Wave bands brandished a similar sound some postulators and pontificator figured was some sort of musical movement. Actually, the limited array of electronic effects limited expression. Everyone except the most gifted opted for an analog sound with a metallic bring that, in the minds of puzzled critics, echoed a pervading sense of a science fiction wasteland washing over the pop world. Weird haircuts did't help the critics and cultural commentators much. Even bands like Yes and Pink Floyd, both of which appeared over a decade beforehand, dealt with a limited deck of electrical trickery. But what was lacking in the seventys-era effects department was made up through technical virtuosity. Keith Emerson's piano and Moog work, like Yes's Rick Wakeman's, was legendary. Today, access to special effects is much easier. Hence another secret to Secret Machines. But the so-called mongrelism of Secret Machines does't send there. Borrowing from an ethic of grunge--wall of guitars--Secret Machines adds flange, echo and dogpiles of distortion. Much doubtless enhances the simplicity of the songwriting. But as anyone who has seen the group perform in a live setting understands, Secret Machines has the skill to kill when it all falls together. These guys played for years in Dallas under the name UFOFU. From all respects they made it to local-hero status. Small change compared to now. However, seeing near-misses splayed everywhere around them--Dallas musicians who, for all right and reason, really should have gone national years before, but did't, mainly due to a black of localized support from Dallas' conservative corporate sector--they departed for New York and are currently slated as "the latest thing from NYC." In fact, at last tally, nearly all the artists in NYC are actually Dallas natives. Before they learned the truth about living in a photo-fascist Plutonian berg with city-wide delusions of grandeur, the trio that transmogrified into Secret Machines was probably a group of normal guys with no idea what was happening around them: Dallas found Kenny G acceptable, and Kenny G was brought forth; Dallas found Jessica Simpson acceptable, and WHAMMO! It's Jessica! Everywhere! In Dallas, Secret Machines is on the other side.
summary: DALLASITE MONGREL-REFUGEES ERECT WALL OF ELECTRICITY

reviewText: i wound up hearing the song "dangerous leaving your front door", and i thought okay, cool band. but i could't quite place what sounded so familur about them, then i was strangely tempted to listen to blink one hundred and eighty-two. and it hit. these guys are nothing but jack ash$t trip off wanna bees. being inspired is fine. but huh looking at someone else, and seeing that as an opratunity to make it, no matter what intensions, you suck!!!!!! forget underoath. and gee that reminds me, what is up with all these little gay weenie shoppers coming out with records that are prices of crud lately? i just don't get it. ooh yeah that reminds me, one last, thing. death to coheed and exist. peace!! find some real music!! right on! rock on! rock and roll is being destroyed, but at least there are few and far between that still at least can be slothful. find them, find them now!!!
summary: yeah, what the other guy said.

reviewText: Lloyd Banks and G-Unit are the hottest wrappers out right now. Shady/Aftermath has the game in a choke hold. The Hunger for More just helps to solidify that. If you don't respect this album, your opinion does't really matter cut you're just latin' on my man. Solid beats, sick lyrics and punchlines. Who's better than G-Unit right now? No one. Look out for Buck and Game later this summer. G-G-G-G G-UNITTTT.

Herky-jerky punk with four part harmony. What more could a music fan ask for? The lyrics are not deep and the music may seem a little repetitive to most, but these guys have infectious energy. I have never seen them live, but I can only imagine it being amazing. Their haunting guitars and so-British-it-isn't-even-funny harmonies should sink in rather quickly. Songs like "Decent Days and Nights" and "A to B" should help you to understand the genius of this band if you need proof.

It does have a Neo soul groove to it but its sexy, soulful, and inspiring what R&B; cats have been failing to realize you done have to have club banners to sell records. Alright, Used to love you, She done have to know, Ordinary People, I can change, and Stay with you are joints you should listen to. Lets get lifted again is pure love making at its best.
summary: Were just Ordinary People who need to buy this!

reviewText: John Legend (born John Stephens) puts out a great debut CD with this one entitled "Get Lifted." His voice is in fine form and the musical arrangements could't be better. Everything is very neatly planned. At times Legend reminisces about this childhood in the song "It Don't Have To Change" featuring the Stephens family. Snoop Dogg himself also contributes so damn well to this album in the song "I Can Change." Look for Kanye West to help out with the songs, too! The quality of the sound is excellent; and the liner notes include (almost) the full lyrics and credits for each song. There are great pictures of John both today and from this childhood; and the credits are very nicely done. One note: this is a review for the CD version that has explicit lyrics. In case this is an issue for you, then this CD is not for you. There's another CD by John Legend for sale on the Amazon web site that does not say "explicit lyrics" but I cannot guarantee that the lyrics on that CD have been edited. I think my favourite song on this album would be a tie between "Ordinary People" and "It Don't Have To Change." John plays the piano so well in the first song and when this own family members come in with "It Don't Have To Change," I was very touched and moved. I could really identify with John's desire to go back to simpler times. John obviously has great talent and can move rather skilfully between slow jams, some elements of ship-hop and contemporary R&B; and soul in general. This is just the beginning for John and already I want this sophomore album! Where do I go to buy it? :-)
summary: John Legend raises the bar and scores a big GOAL!

reviewText: Ok so I'm not sure where her first name went, but that does't really matter. I first heard of Utada from the Kingdom Hearts commercials where her song, Simple and Clean, was remixed and played. I liked it enough, but once I got my hands on the original english version, you'd better believe I was hooked. Where did this girl get such an amazing voice??!?! So when I saw her on the new release track at my job, I immediately put it aside to buy it later. And then I found it on a listening station, and listened for maybe a minute. The intro had me hooked even more. I did't need to hear the rest, but I did. She manages to utilize the talents of amazing producers, and Timbaland while she's at it, to beautifully showcase her voice and lyrical ability. These songs are captivating, intoxicating, and infectious. She will be a big player in the pop scene, you watch.

After the successful "Chicken & Beer", which hit in two thousand and three, plus many other production (Chingy, Shawnna, one-twenty, etc.), Luda comes out with this fourth LP, not including "Incognegro". Although this album is slightly usual material, the whole album than't been played before it came out, like "Chicken & Beer". He shows all sides of this genre. He goes back to this southern roots in "Hopeless", gets it trunk with "Who Not Me", visits the wild, wild west with "Spur Of The Moment" and returns to this usual Luda self "Pass Out". Although its kinda mediocre, its probably one of this best. It's surprising me that the album was't better. With this rhyme play, Luda could come out with a classic LP, but until then, this could definitely do.

I enjoyed this album thoroughly, one of my favourite pop cd of the year. The reason I say pop is because that's what this is, Get Rich Or Die Tryin' was not pop, but this is. I like both albums equally, though Get Rich has a slight edge, I still like fifty just as much. All the videos are good, and I feel fifty Cent is the smartest man in the business as far as marketing and sales go. Highlights include God Gave Me Style, Position of Power, and pretty much the whole CD. Make your next CD hardcore street lyrics fifty, if anyone will even accept that from you after this pop album. I guess I should say this is more a pop-street album, but either way, its tight as hell, so, yeah, cop it. Dont go expecting the grimy lyrics that someone like Young Jeezy for Jadakiss offer, but expect a classic "pop-street" album.

I bought this blind. Had read a few reviews, and the title had come up on a few lists of past favourites. This is like finding a chunk of gold when you hit on a piece of music like this. After three for four listens. you will need a pair of pliers to get this out of your player. A smash of hooks, melodies, and strange movements that will stay in your collection forever. A quality recording.
summary: More hooks than your daddy's tackle box.
